in canada , and their potential to shape a better future for everyone . youth in canada are engaged , resourceful , and resilient . they are the leaders of tomorrow , and of today . they understand crisis . that is why the government of canada has made investments to support vulnerable youth , including those facing barriers to employment , as well as to make it easier for young people to pursue , many of whom are facing barriers to meaningful participation in society . through my work as minister of diversity and inclusion and youth , i’ve had the opportunity to meet with many of these youth and i’ve seen how committed they are to building a better country . like prime minister justin trudeau , i believe in the power of youth - which is why it was so important to ensure that this report was developed “for youth , with youth , and by youth” . while it might be the first report of its kind , we know that it is a continuation of our government’s longstanding commitment to build a better future for youth in canada . we must also remember that youth in canada represent a diverse cross-section of society as individuals with unique circumstances based in part on where they live , their stage in life , and their background . these intersectional identities contribute to the rich diversity of our country , but sometimes also hinder youth from reaching their full potential . with this I am delighted to introduce the inaugural State of Youth Report. This comprehensive document is the result of extensive input from nearly 1,000 young individuals from diverse backgrounds across Canada. It highlights the valuable contributions of youth in our country and recognizes their potential to shape a brighter future for all.

The youth in Canada are actively engaged, resourceful, and resilient. They are not only the leaders of tomorrow but also of today. They possess a deep understanding of the most pressing issues our nation faces and have the innovative ideas and solutions to tackle them. This report focuses on their primary concerns, including truth finding and reconciliation with Indigenous peoples, environmental sustainability and climate action, health and well-being, leadership and impact, employment, and innovation, skills, and learning. It showcases their perspectives on these matters and presents their vision for creating a more inclusive and prosperous Canada.

The past year has presented significant challenges for everyone due to the global pandemic, and Canadian youth have been disproportionately affected. They have made tremendous sacrifices to protect their families and must be at the forefront of our recovery efforts as we rebuild and emerge stronger from this crisis. The Government of Canada has made strategic investments to support vulnerable youth, including those facing employment barriers. Additionally, measures have been implemented to facilitate access to education, alleviate student debt, and provide training and employment opportunities. By investing in our youth, we are investing in Canada's long-term success and prosperity.

I extend my sincerest gratitude to the hundreds of young individuals who contributed to the creation of this report, as well as all those involved in its preparation. As the former Minister of Youth, I am committed to advancing this vital work through the Youth Council and the continued implementation of Canada's first-ever youth policy. Our government will continue to listen to the voices of young people, collaborate with them, and take action to empower them to drive change in their communities and turn their dreams into reality.

The State of Youth Report is truly unique in its approach, serving as a reminder that youth across the country are brimming with fresh and innovative ideas to address our most complex challenges. The recommendations contained within this report are the culmination of engagement sessions with approximately 1,000 young individuals, including First Nations, Métis, Inuit, Black, racialized, and LGBTQ2 youth. Many of these young individuals face barriers to meaningful participation in society. In my role as Minister of Diversity and Inclusion and Youth, I have had the privilege of meeting many of these inspiring youth, witnessing their unwavering commitment to building a better Canada. Like Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, I firmly believe in the power of youth, which is why it was crucial to develop this report "for youth, with youth, and by youth."

While this may be the first report of its kind, it aligns with our government's longstanding commitment to creating a brighter future for Canadian youth. It is important to recognize that youth in Canada represent a diverse cross-section of society, each with unique circumstances based on their location, life stage, and background. These intersecting identities contribute to the rich diversity of our nation but can also pose challenges to youth reaching their full potential. With this in mind, I invite you to read this report, reflect on the recommendations, and gain further insight into the state of young people in our country, including the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their lives. Only by listening to and hearing from our young leaders can we forge a better future for all Canadians.

when ewan reid passionately describes that his software is going to the moon next year , it’s hard to imagine he almost became a banker . but an exciting opportunity at an aerospace company and landing a job as a shuttle flight controller at the kennedy space center in florida in 2008 changed his course and set him on the path to working in the aerospace industry . reid is the founder and ceo of mission control , an ottawa-based space exploration and robotics company incorporated in 2015 . from its humble beginnings to producing software destined for the moon , the company has reached new heights and will mark a significant milestone next year . mission control teamed up with the mohammed bin rashid space centre in dubai , united arab emirates , to help a small rover navigate the moon’s terrain . mission control’s cutting-edge artificial intelligence software operates robots via the internet . back on earth , mission control’s software will send data almost in real time to scientists at 4 canadian universities who will work with the dubai space centre team to decide where the rover should go . this partnership with the mohammed bin rashid space centre allows mission control to demonstrate their technology for the first time in space . “this is the first canadian software , the first canadian computer , the first canadian artificial intelligence to go to the moon , ” said reid . “i’m really proud of our team and honoured for us to be , in a way , representing canada on the emirates’ lunar mission . ” there’s no doubt that mission control is ready for its first foray into space , which could open up many opportunities for the company . they’ve been practising with the little bit of “space” they brought to their office a 4 , 000-square-foot room constructed to look like the surface of the moon , where they drive rovers using their software . dubbed the “moonyard” by the company , it’s a testing facility with sand , rocks , craters , black walls and lights that simulate the sun where mission control and partners can practise before going on real moon explorations . mission control was proud to share their world-class facility and software in dubai in 2021 . reid and several colleagues travelled to expo 2020 dubai and the international astronautical congress to share their work with a global audience . “it’s critical in the space industry to work with international space organizations . almost no space missions can be completed by a single country , ” said reid . “going to something like expo is really important for us to build those relationships , those partnerships , and ultimately execute exciting and important space missions . ” canada’s trade commissioner service ( tcs ) has helped mission control explore markets in israel , italy , japan , mexico and the united arab emirates . during a trade mission to the united arab emirates in 2019 , reid met with officials from the mohammed bin rashid space centre for the first time . and in japan , the tcs introduced reid to ispace , a lunar exploration company that is crucial to the mohammed bin rashid space centre mission . an ispace lander will carry the space centre’s rover and mission control’s software to the moon . the tcs ensured mission control had a “soft landing” in international markets to forge new partnerships for this ottawa start-up company and help it reach new heights .

Ewan Reid, the founder and CEO of Mission Control, an Ottawa-based space exploration and robotics company, has come a long way from almost becoming a banker. In 2008, Reid seized an exciting opportunity at an aerospace company and landed a job as a shuttle flight controller at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. This experience redirected his career path towards the aerospace industry.

Since its inception in 2015, Mission Control has grown from humble beginnings to producing software that is destined for the moon. The company is proud to announce a significant milestone next year as it partners with the Mohammed bin Rashid Space Centre in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, to assist a small rover in navigating the moon's terrain. Mission Control's cutting-edge artificial intelligence software enables the operation of robots remotely via the internet. On Earth, the software will transmit near real-time data to scientists at four Canadian universities who will collaborate with the Dubai Space Centre team to determine the rover's path.

This collaboration with the Mohammed bin Rashid Space Centre presents an opportunity for Mission Control to showcase its technology in space for the first time. Ewan Reid expresses his pride in the team's achievements and their honor in representing Canada on the Emirates' lunar mission. This endeavor is the first instance of Canadian software, computer, and artificial intelligence being deployed on the moon.

Mission Control is fully prepared for this inaugural venture into space, which could potentially unlock numerous opportunities for the company. They have been practicing their software by driving rovers in a simulated lunar environment at their 4,000-square-foot office, aptly named the "Moonyard." This testing facility replicates the moon's surface with sand, rocks, craters, black walls, and simulated sunlight. This dedicated space allows Mission Control and its partners to rehearse before embarking on actual lunar explorations.

In 2021, Mission Control proudly showcased their world-class facility and software at Expo 2020 Dubai and the International Astronautical Congress, reaching a global audience. Ewan Reid emphasizes the importance of collaborating with international space organizations in the industry, as very few space missions can be accomplished by a single country. Participating in events like Expo is crucial for establishing relationships, forging partnerships, and executing significant space missions.

The Canadian Trade Commissioner Service (TCS) has played a vital role in supporting Mission Control's growth by facilitating their exploration of markets in Israel, Italy, Japan, Mexico, and the United Arab Emirates. During a trade mission to the UAE in 2019, Ewan Reid met with officials from the Mohammed bin Rashid Space Centre for the first time. Additionally, through the TCS, Reid was introduced to iSpace, a lunar exploration company in Japan that is integral to the Mohammed bin Rashid Space Centre mission. iSpace's lander will transport the space centre's rover and Mission Control's software to the moon. The TCS has effectively assisted Mission Control in expanding its presence in international markets, nurturing new partnerships, and achieving new heights.

August 1, 2023, marks the 50th anniversary of the opening of the Lester B. Pearson Building, a symbol of Canada's international involvement. Located at 125 Sussex Drive in Ottawa, it serves as the headquarters of Global Affairs Canada, accommodating approximately 3,300 employees. Today, we take a moment to celebrate the rich history and enduring legacy of this building. 

The Lester B. Pearson Building is situated on the traditional and unceded territory of the Algonquin Anishinaabeg people and holds a prominent position on Sussex Drive, along the ceremonial route from Parliament Hill to Rideau Hall, the Governor General's residence. With its four office towers, this building represents a significant chapter in Canada's architectural and governmental heritage.

Designed by the esteemed firm Webb Zerafa Menkès Housden and constructed between 1970 and 1973, the building was named in honor of Lester B. Pearson, an esteemed Prime Minister, diplomat, and Nobel Peace Prize winner. Pearson's visionary leadership resulted in historic contributions to peacekeeping, including the establishment of the United Nations Emergency Force. In 1973, a government spokesman aptly stated to The New York Times, "it is appropriate that Canada's first physical expression of its relations with the rest of the world be named for Mr. Pearson."

The architectural brilliance of the building showcases the late modern movement, incorporating elements of brutalism. The design aimed to create a sense of repose, quiet dignity, precision, and restraint. Strong horizontal lines, an organic form, and the use of dark materials brought this vision to life. As a result, the building has become a landmark, leaving a lasting impression on all who visit the bustling neighborhood.

Over the past five decades, the Lester B. Pearson Building has served as the epicenter of the department now known as Global Affairs Canada. Its halls have witnessed historic events, state visits, and significant diplomatic engagements. Queen Elizabeth II officially opened the building on August 1, 1973, expressing her joy that the ceremony coincided with her first Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, underscoring the moment's significance for Commonwealth nations.

The dedicated foreign service officers and diplomatic leaders working at the building have played a pivotal role in promoting and safeguarding Canada's interests on the global stage. Throughout the past 50 years, the Lester B. Pearson Building has housed public servants who have championed causes such as human rights, gender equality, and peacekeeping worldwide. The department has advanced Canada's foreign policy objectives, showcased the nation's values, and provided a strong voice in international forums.

Recognizing the need to evolve with the changing world, a large-scale rehabilitation project was announced in 2017. The renovation includes upgraded plumbing and electrical systems to enhance the building's environmental performance and aims for Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) Gold certification. The interior spaces are being transformed to align with the new government of Canada standard for offices, emphasizing collaboration and flexibility introduced in 2022.

As we celebrate 50 years of the Lester B. Pearson Building, we pay tribute to its remarkable heritage. This iconic structure remains a steadfast embodiment of Canada's commitment to diplomacy, collaboration, and global engagement. Let us draw inspiration from the values and principles it represents as we forge ahead to foster peace, prosperity, and cooperation on the world stage.

canada was one of the first countries in the world to put in place a feminist international assistance policy in 2017 . but what does having a feminist approach to international assistance mean ? are we leaving men and boys behind to prioritize women ? absolutely not . the feminist international assistance policy ( fiap ) is feminist because it addresses the root causes of poverty through an intersectional , human rights-based and feminist lens , meaning it considers multiple and overlapping forms of discrimination . this enablesus to identify the groups and individuals in situations of extreme poverty , vulnerability and marginalization . the fiap looks to level the playing field by addressing key barriers to equality . this is important because we cannot eliminate poverty without considering the needs of different groups of people . an estimated 55% of the global population faces instability and poverty . entrenched gender inequalities affect women and girls more than men and boys , and in different ways . this is true both in canada and around the world , particularly for women and groups pushed to the peripheries of society . to create a more peaceful and prosperous world for everyone , we need to tackle inequalities so that people — no matter their gender identity or expression , sex characteristics or other identity factors — can fully enjoy their human rights . the feminist policy’s goal is to reduce poverty around the world interventions that advance gender equality are proven to make the most significant progress toward this goal . a united nations study found that closing the gender gap on farms and in agrifood systems would increase global gross domestic product by nearly a trillion us dollars . this would reduce the number of food-insecure people by 45 million . that’s 1 of many statistics that illustrate current inequality . if half of small-scale producers benefited from development interventions that focused on empowering women , it would significantly raise the incomes of an additional 58 million people and increase the resilience of an additional 235 million people . this is why canada funds projects like seedchange , which ensured women made up 50% of the leadership positions in collective enterprises like farming co-ops and increased participation in traditionally male-dominated areas . seedchange targeted the central american dry corridor , burkina faso , mali and ethiopia , where it helped increase seed , food and economic security for 26 , 046 small-scale farm households . as a result of the project , households grew more fruits and vegetables , along with more diverse crops , making more food available to families living in poverty . the data collected over five years proved the project led tohealthier diets , better livelihoods , improved climate resilience , and greater autonomy in every community . more than 100 women’s groups and almost 40 youth-run co-ops broke down the barriers they faced to entering the marketplace . in gaza , female-headed households are far more likely to live in poverty and experience pronounced inequality in a society where traditional gender roles dominate . through the canada-funded salalem leadership institute , sarah , a single parent of 2 , joined an 8-week entrepreneurship training program and received support for her agricultural startup . “i was born and raised as a farmer , ” says sarah . “since i was young , i have grown and tended to the plants . with the help of my mother and brothers , i succeeded to start my dream business that will provide my children a secured future . ” sarah received mentorship support through salalem to improve fer farming practices and expand her business . sarah has so far harvested crops for at least 6 consecutive farming seasons . after one year of successfully running her business she was able to rent a bigger piece of land to diversify and increase her farming productions . she also bought goats , which helped her to start up an animal breeding and productions line .

Canada implemented a feminist international assistance policy in 2017, making it one of the pioneers in this area. But what exactly does a feminist approach to international assistance entail? Contrary to the misconception that it solely prioritizes women and leaves men and boys behind, the policy is feminist because it tackles the underlying causes of poverty through an intersectional, human rights-based, and feminist lens. This means it takes into account various forms of discrimination that people face, enabling us to identify those in extreme poverty, vulnerability, and marginalization.

The goal of the policy is to create a more equitable society by addressing key barriers to equality. It recognizes that poverty cannot be eliminated without considering the diverse needs of different groups. Women and girls are disproportionately affected by entrenched gender inequalities, both in Canada and globally, particularly those marginalized within society. To truly build a peaceful and prosperous world, we must confront these inequalities so that everyone can fully enjoy their human rights, regardless of their gender identity, expression, sex characteristics, or other identity factors.

Interventions that advance gender equality have been proven to have the most significant impact on reducing poverty worldwide. A United Nations study revealed that closing the gender gap in farming and agrifood systems could boost global gross domestic product by almost a trillion US dollars and reduce the number of food-insecure individuals by 45 million. This statistic highlights the current inequalities that persist.

Canada supports initiatives like SeedChange, which focuses on empowering women and ensuring their representation in leadership positions within collective enterprises such as farming co-ops. SeedChange has made a significant impact in the Central American dry corridor, Burkina Faso, Mali, and Ethiopia, improving seed, food, and economic security for over 26,000 small-scale farm households. The project has resulted in the growth of more fruits, vegetables, and diverse crops, making nutritious food more accessible to families living in poverty. The data collected over five years demonstrates that the project has led to healthier diets, better livelihoods, improved climate resilience, and increased autonomy in every community. Over 100 women's groups and almost 40 youth-run co-ops have overcome barriers to enter the marketplace.

In Gaza, female-headed households experience higher poverty rates and pronounced inequality due to traditional gender roles prevailing in society. Through the Canada-funded Salalem Leadership Institute, Sarah, a single mother of two, participated in an eight-week entrepreneurship training program and received support for her agricultural startup. With the help of her mother and brothers, Sarah successfully started her dream business, providing a secure future for her children. Salalem provided her with mentorship to enhance her farming practices and expand her business. Sarah has now completed six consecutive farming seasons, and after a year of running her business successfully, she was able to rent a larger piece of land to diversify and increase her farming production. She also ventured into animal breeding and production by acquiring goats.

These examples demonstrate the positive impact of Canada's feminist international assistance policy in reducing poverty and empowering individuals and communities around the world.

the commercial building you choose will have a big impact on your business . ideally , its size , layout , location and appearance should all enhance your operations while respecting zoning and environmental regulations . commercial buildings come in a wide variety of shapes , locations and prices , so you have to know what your needs are and how much you can afford to pay . if you ' ve worked on a business plan , you probably know the amount you can spend on rent or a mortgage , utilities and taxes . a cash-flow analysis will help you determine whether you can afford to purchase a commercial property or if renting is your only viable option . renting may allow you to keep more of your working capital for business operations . still , don ' t forget to take future rent increases into account . when you own your property , you know what your monthly mortgage payments will be and you are building equity for your business . be sure to weigh out your options when deciding to buy or lease you commercial space . in the meantime , here are five tips to help guide your thinking when searching for the right location for your business . 1 . adapt your selection to the needs of your business if you ' re a retailer , you probably want to make sure there ' s ample parking and pedestrian traffic as well as attractive decor . situating your business close to a magnet or anchor store can provide you with lots of walk-by customers . if you sell high-end clothing , for example , it ' s probably best to avoid discount malls and instead locate your business close to other high-end retailers such as shoe stores or jewelers . location and decor are less important to the success of a small wholesale or manufacturing operation , but you will have to comply with zoning regulations that stipulate what types of activity are allowed where . you should also consider the availability of qualified employees within a half-hour commute of where you are considering buying . for personal , professional or creative services , you may require a series of closed offices in pleasant surroundings with high-speed networking and easy access to public transit . the ability to attract and retain qualified employees can be critical to success of such businesses , so a building in a central , easily accessible location can give you a strategic advantage . when considering a loading dock , for instance , ask yourself is it well situated ? does it require repair ? are there more than one in the facility ? 2 . does it require modification ? if you ' ve found a suitable building in a good location , consider what it will take to make it just right . the question then becomes , who will pay ? if you ' re renting premises that require modification , you ' ll have to negotiate with the owner . make sure you have a contract specifying what needs to be done , with clear deadlines and penalties for not completing the work on time . these provisions need to be written into your lease . if you want to buy , use an accredited inspection company to evaluate the building for defects and the entire property for environmental contamination . defects can be points for negotiation with the seller—or signs of future headaches best avoided altogether . not all changes are within the power of an owner to complete . there may be zoning or heritage regulations that require renovations to be approved by a local board . even a minor change , like inserting a shipping door into an old brick façade , can require municipal approval . this can take time , and there ' s no guarantee the changes requested will be allowed . 3 . consider local taxes and infrastructure taxes vary between municipalities , with some towns offering preferential rates in the hopes of attracting businesses . your commercial real estate agent should know what the taxes will be , as well as the infrastructure and utilities—including internet access , garbage pickup , roads , electricity and natural gas—that are available at the sites you ' re considering .

Choosing the right commercial building for your business is a crucial decision that can greatly impact your operations. It is important to consider factors such as size, layout, location, and appearance while also adhering to zoning and environmental regulations.

Commercial buildings come in various shapes, locations, and price ranges, so it is essential to understand your specific needs and budget. If you have worked on a business plan, you likely have an idea of how much you can allocate towards rent or a mortgage, utilities, and taxes. Conducting a cash-flow analysis will help determine if purchasing a property is feasible or if renting is the more viable option. Renting may allow you to retain more working capital for your business, but it is important to consider future rent increases. On the other hand, owning a property provides the advantage of predictable monthly mortgage payments and the opportunity to build equity for your business. It is crucial to carefully evaluate and compare your options before deciding whether to buy or lease your commercial space.

In the meantime, here are five tips to assist you in finding the ideal location for your business:

1. Tailor your selection to suit the needs of your business. For retailers, ample parking, pedestrian traffic, and attractive decor are important. Being situated near popular stores can attract walk-by customers. However, if you sell high-end clothing, it may be more suitable to avoid discount malls and instead be located near other high-end retailers. For small wholesale or manufacturing operations, while location and decor are less vital, compliance with zoning regulations is necessary. Additionally, consider the availability of qualified employees within a reasonable commute.

2. Assess if the building requires modifications. If you have found a suitable building in a desirable location, it is important to consider the necessary modifications and who will bear the costs. When renting, negotiations with the owner are required, and a contract specifying the work, deadlines, and penalties must be established. When purchasing, engage an accredited inspection company to evaluate the building for defects and the property for environmental contamination. Defects can be bargaining points or potential headaches to avoid. It is also crucial to be aware of zoning or heritage regulations, as even minor changes may require municipal approval.

3. Consider local taxes and infrastructure. Taxes differ between municipalities, and some towns offer preferential rates to attract businesses. Your commercial real estate agent should be able to provide information on taxes as well as the availability of infrastructure and utilities, such as internet access, garbage pickup, roads, electricity, and natural gas.

national parks are among the world ' s natural jewels . they represent the power of canada ' s natural environment which has shaped not only the geography of this country , but also the course of its history and the experiences of the people who live and travel here . national parks are established to protect and present outstanding representative examples of natural landscapes and phenomena that occur in each of canada ' s unique natural regions , as identified in the national parks system plan . when establishing new parks , other considerations include the area’s ecological connectivity with other regions and whether the area is represented or underrepresented within the system plan . these wild places , located in every province and territory , range from mountains and plains , to boreal forests and tundra , to lakes and glaciers , and beyond . national parks protect the habitats , wildlife , and ecosystem diversity representative of these natural regions . national parks are located on the atlantic , pacific , and arctic coasts , across the interior mountains , plains and great lakes . they range in size from 14 km2 ( georgian bay islands national park of canada ) to almost 45 , 000 km2 ( wood buffalo national park of canada ) . and they include world-renowned names such as banff and jasper , as well as more recently established ivvavik and vuntut . parks canada is responsible for both protecting the ecosystems of these magnificent natural areas and managing them for visitors to understand , appreciate , and enjoy in a way that doesn ' t compromise their integrity . understanding and appreciating the breathtaking scenery and natural surroundings of national parks provide the perfect setting for tuning into nature , respecting it , and pledging to protect it . each national park is a haven for the human spirit . national parks tell the stories of the natural beginnings of these lands--mountains forming , lakes emerging , rivers running , forests growing , glaciers moving , grasslands evolving . they reveal ongoing natural processes--floods , fires and the migration of species . they provide opportunities to connect with nature , people and the events that define the peoples of these lands . visitors can paddle down rivers flowing through canyons carved over thousands of years , observe birds as they rest in their travels along traditional migration routes , walk through vibrant young forests transformed by fire . these are unforgettable experiences , made all the more memorable by the rich experiences parks canada National parks are cherished natural treasures that showcase Canada's extraordinary environment, shaping the country's geography, history, and the experiences of its inhabitants and visitors. These parks serve as protected havens that present outstanding examples of the diverse natural landscapes and phenomena found in each of Canada's distinct regions. When establishing new parks, factors such as ecological connectivity and representation within the system plan are also taken into consideration.

Spanning across every province and territory, national parks encompass a wide range of landscapes, including mountains, plains, boreal forests, tundra, lakes, and glaciers. They safeguard the habitats, wildlife, and ecosystem diversity that characterize these natural regions. From the Atlantic, Pacific, and Arctic coasts to the interior mountains, plains, and great lakes, national parks occupy various locations and vary in size from 14 km2 to almost 45,000 km2. Some well-known parks include Banff, Jasper, Ivavik, and Vuntut.

Parks Canada holds the responsibility of protecting and managing these breathtaking natural areas, ensuring their preservation and offering visitors the opportunity to understand, appreciate, and enjoy them without compromising their integrity. The captivating scenery and surroundings of national parks provide an ideal setting for connecting with nature, fostering respect, and making a commitment to its conservation.

Each national park is a sanctuary for the human spirit, narrating the natural origins of these lands and the ongoing processes that shape them, such as mountain formation, lake emergence, forest growth, glacier movements, and grassland evolution. Moreover, they allow visitors to witness natural events like floods, fires, and species migration. These experiences forge connections with nature, people, and the defining events of the regions. Whether kayaking down ancient rivers, observing migratory birds, or exploring vibrant forests regenerated by fire, national parks offer truly unforgettable encounters, enriched by the exceptional experiences provided by Parks Canada.

Preserving ecological integrity is a fundamental objective for Parks Canada, as it strives to maintain or restore the health and wholeness of national park ecosystems. This entails ensuring the biodiversity, structure, and functions of ecosystems remain unimpaired and likely to persist. National parks hold a special place in the hearts of Canadians, serving as a source of pride and an integral part of our national identity, celebrating the remarkable beauty and limitless diversity of our land.

The National Parks System Plan identifies and aims to safeguard each of Canada's unique natural regions. This strategic framework has guided the expansion of the parks system for many years. For a PDF copy of the National Park System Plan (1997), please contact us at information@pc.gc.ca.

Imagine the incredible feat of traveling across the 92km width of Lake Erie. This seemingly impossible task is successfully accomplished by tiny monarch butterflies. Not only do they traverse the Great Lakes, but they also migrate across entire countries. However, the journey for these at-risk species is becoming increasingly challenging each year.

During the fall, monarch butterflies escape the cold through migration. They travel from southern Canada all the way down to Mexico to spend the winter. In the spring, a new generation of butterflies embarks on a journey of thousands of kilometers from Mexico. They cross the United States, traversing fields, mountains, and even the Great Lakes, to return to Canada and start the cycle again.

Consider the implications if the butterflies arrived back in Canada only to find asphalt and mowed grass. They would have no sustenance or resting places to recover. Parks Canada is actively working to prevent this scenario and we need your assistance!

Fortunately, when many monarchs cross Lake Erie from the United States, they are welcomed by Point Pelee National Park. Point Pelee, the southernmost point of mainland Canada, is the most ecologically diverse national park in the country. Here, the butterflies find an abundance of food and shelter for much-needed rest after their arduous journey. Some butterflies then continue north and east throughout Ontario, potentially finding summer homes in Parks Canada administered areas such as Bruce Peninsula National Park, Rouge National Urban Park, Georgian Bay Islands National Park, and more. These locations serve as stops along their migration.

However, as these butterflies venture beyond national parks, they encounter landscape fragmentation. Urban development, roads, industrial agriculture, and other factors have led to the loss and fragmentation of their habitat. The need to travel longer distances in search of suitable habitats exacerbates their already difficult journey.

In order to support the monarch butterfly and other at-risk species, Parks Canada is actively restoring ecosystems to provide stepping stones of habitat. These stops enable species to move more freely and easily within their natural environment. By planting native trees, grasses, and wildflowers in protected areas, Parks Canada is creating food and habitat where migrating birds and butterflies can rest and refuel before continuing their journey.

Together with indigenous communities, partners, and volunteers, Parks Canada has restored over 40 hectares (98.8 acres) of meadow, coastal sand dune, and savannah habitat in national parks in Ontario. These habitats are crucial for pollinators. Over the past five years, we have also planted more than 145,000 native shrubs and trees, as well as nearly 18,000 native grasses and wildflowers. Our work to conserve and restore healthy ecosystems that provide important habitat is just one part of a larger puzzle.

You, too, can contribute to the solution of habitat loss by providing habitat "stepping stones". Imagine if, once a monarch butterfly moves on from a national park, it found your yard, garden box, or balcony filled with native plants. There, it could rest and refuel before continuing its journey to another protected area. Even planting a few native plants or wildflowers can significantly ease the butterfly's journey. It doesn't require a large yard to make a difference – planting a small garden or a few native plants on your balcony is equally important, especially in urban areas. If you don't have the space to plant at home, consider joining a community garden in your neighborhood.

To help pollinators, we recommend planting a variety of native plants and wildflowers. Milkweed is particularly beneficial for monarchs, as it is the only plant that their caterpillars eat. Consult Pollinator Partnership Canada's ecoregional planting guides or their 'Find Your Roots' native plant finder tool for recommended plants in your area. You can also refer to the Canadian Wildlife Federation's list of Canadian native plant suppliers to support local businesses when purchasing plants and seeds.

Wetlands, characterized by their mixture of water and land, possess a unique beauty and ecological significance. Unfortunately, these areas are often overlooked and disregarded. One reason for their neglect is their ambiguous nature, residing neither fully on land nor in water. Dr. Chantal Vis, an expert in aquatic ecosystems at Parks Canada, explains that studying wetlands presents challenges because limited research can be conducted from both land and boats. Additionally, wetlands are undervalued due to their historical reputation as wastelands. Throughout history, wetlands have been drained to make way for agriculture and development, an unfortunate trend that continues today. Southern Ontario has lost a staggering 68 percent of its wetlands, while urban areas in the prairies have witnessed losses of up to 96 percent.

Commonly associated with negative imagery in popular culture, such as snakes and monsters, wetlands actually provide a multitude of valuable services to society. Jim Stafford's song "Swamp Witch" perpetuates these misconceptions, but to portray the truth, he could have included a line about the ecosystem services wetlands offer. These services range from carbon storage to flood and pollution control. Rather than fearing the multitude of eyes present in wetlands, they are a testament to the biological richness found within them.

Wetlands function as biofilters, allowing water to pass through and settle sediment, while microbes break down pollutants within it. Wetland vegetation, such as cattails and bulrushes, further aid in pollutant removal, absorbing toxic heavy metals and fertilizer residues. This capability has earned wetlands the nickname "nature's kidneys." Moreover, wetlands play a crucial role in flood and erosion control, slowing and absorbing water during periods of heavy rainfall and then gradually releasing stored water during dry spells. Their significance extends beyond their immediate surroundings, as wetlands absorb carbon dioxide, a major greenhouse gas contributing to climate change. Bogs, specifically, with their peat-filled soil, are particularly effective at this.

Biological diversity thrives within wetlands, making them ecological hotspots. Scientists estimate that around one-third of all North American species at risk rely on wetlands. Globally, wetlands also provide fuel and building materials. Recognizing the value of wetlands, Ontario's Rouge National Urban Park has embarked on extensive restoration efforts in collaboration with the Toronto and Region Conservation Authority, schools, community groups, and indigenous partners. Since 2015, they have restored over 60 hectares of wetland, stream, and riverbank habitats, often replicating wetlands where they historically existed. Julia Phillips, an ecologist at Rouge, explains that this process involves careful consideration of drainage lines and implementing berms to retain water on the landscape, mimicking the behavior of beavers.

These wetland restoration efforts have yielded numerous benefits, including the filtration of agricultural runoff and reduced flooding on farmers' fields. Additionally, wetlands contribute to the preservation of a spongy landscape that once existed naturally. The work at Rouge and other national parks emphasizes the role of wetlands as crucial natural engineering systems that foster a healthy environment. Dr. Chantal Vis emphasizes the importance of recognizing wetlands as habitats that have suffered the most losses, stating that despite the immense value they offer, they are not given the appreciation they deserve. Perhaps, someone should compose a song to convey their significance to a wider audience.

The European green crab, often referred to as a marine cockroach or green menace, is considered one of the world's 10 most unwanted species. However, this despised crustacean may hold the key to addressing the global issue of plastic pollution. Parks Canada has partnered with Dr. Audrey Moores, a chemistry professor at McGill University, to explore the possibility of producing biodegradable plastic from the shells of European green crabs. This collaboration, described as a "marriage made in heaven" by Chris McCarthy, Resource Conservation Manager for Parks Canada, highlights the irony of a green pest contributing to the field of "green chemistry."

The partnership began when Dr. Moores published a paper on utilizing chitin, the material found in the shells of insects and crustaceans, for the production of biodegradable plastic. This paper caught the attention of Gabrielle Beaulieu, Coastal Restoration Project Manager at Kejimkujik National Park and Historic Site in Nova Scotia. Kejimkujik was dealing with an invasion of green crabs, a common issue in Atlantic North America. Ms. Beaulieu and Mr. McCarthy approached Dr. Moores with the idea of turning their problem into a solution, or at the very least, utilizing it as raw material for a solution. Dr. Moores expressed great interest in their initiative, leading to a successful crowdfunding campaign through the Fathom Fund, a project of the Marine Environmental Observation Prediction and Response Network (MEOPAR). Parks Canada will contribute $20,000 to the project, enabling the hiring of a full-time researcher based near Kejimkujik.

Kejimkujik's struggle with green crabs began in 2007 when conservation staff noticed the alarming decline of eelgrass, a vital marine plant that serves as a nursery for several commercially fished species in Nova Scotia. By 2010, eelgrass coverage in the Port Joli Estuary had decreased to only 2% of its levels in 1987. The disappearance of eelgrass had detrimental effects on marine species and the birds that rely on them for food. Adult green crabs would uproot eelgrass while searching for their prey, which includes clams, mussels, oysters, smaller crabs, and even small fish. To combat this issue, Kejimkujik began trapping and removing green crabs with the help of rowboats and canoes. A citizen science initiative called "Gone Crabbin'" was introduced, allowing park visitors to participate in the control program. To date, over 2 million green crabs have been removed from estuary locations within the park, leading to the recovery of nearly 40% of the original eelgrass beds and the overall improvement of estuarine biodiversity. Kejimkujik has also successfully encouraged the use of green crabs as lobster bait and as a source of food.

The partnership between Parks Canada and Dr. Moores not only benefits coastal communities and ecosystems but also holds potential for improving ocean health. Conventional plastic poses a significant problem for the world's oceans, as it does not break down and can contaminate the food chain. Approximately one-third of the world's plastic ends up in the ocean. While biodegradable plastic made from chitin already exists, it is currently produced on a small scale and can be environmentally harmful. Dr. Moores' approach utilizes green chemistry to produce the plastic cleanly and on a larger scale. Thus, the despised European green crab may one day contribute to the well-being of the ocean. It is indeed rewarding when a notorious villain becomes a force for good, or at least a provider of ingredients for positive work.

Ongoing discussions are taking place towards the creation of a comprehensive trade agreement, building on the progress made in 2016. The second annual leaders’ dialogue was successfully concluded, during which a variety of key issues were discussed and the bilateral relationship was strengthened. Both sides have agreed to continue exploratory discussions in order to create more opportunities for people in both countries through a comprehensive trade agreement. 

Regarding the resolution of agrifood market access, Canada and China are committed to fully implementing the 2016 agreement. This will expand market access for Canadian frozen bone-in beef and Chinese filled grain products. Additionally, a pilot project will be initiated for the export of Canadian chilled beef and pork. 

In the partnership on natural resources and energy, Canada and China will collaborate to reduce emissions, promote clean energy solutions, and support economic growth while ensuring environmental protection. Both sides expressed their support for establishing new Sino-Canadian eco-districts and tall wood structures, utilizing Canadian wood products and energy-efficient technologies. Furthermore, the Canada-China Track II Energy Dialogue will be launched to provide advice and strengthen trade and investment between the two countries. 

Continued law enforcement cooperation is crucial in combating the illicit manufacture and trafficking of fentanyl and other opioids, as illicit drug trafficking knows no borders. In the context of the national security and rule of law dialogue, the Prime Minister has directed officials to intensify efforts in addressing the opioid threat. China's efforts to disrupt the illicit trafficking of fentanyl were welcomed by Canada, including their classification of various controlled substances under Chinese law and their investigation of leads provided by foreign law enforcement. 

Canada and China reaffirmed their support for further opportunities in youth exchanges and international education. The signing of a memorandum of understanding concerning the Canada Learning Initiative in China (CLIC) was welcomed, facilitating China's ongoing funding of CLIC scholarships for Canadian post-secondary students. Canada will provide $4.1 million over five years to support related initiatives, including increasing opportunities for Canadian youth to study in China and providing youth internships at Canadian missions in China. 

In terms of defence and security, Canada and China will continue to strengthen military-to-military interactions, including a planned Royal Canadian Navy port visit to China in 2018. Both sides will enhance exchanges and cooperation in the areas of UN peacekeeping, humanitarian assistance, and disaster response. The importance of the Women, Peace, and Security agenda was emphasized within the context of cooperation on UN peace operations and ongoing academic exchanges. 

To accommodate the Canada-China Year of Tourism and the expected growth in tourist flows, proportional growth in air transport services was highlighted as necessary by the Prime Minister. The two leaders committed to exploring ways to expand these services in the near future. 

Canada and China agreed to further engage and collaborate on pressing regional and global challenges, exchanging views on North Korea and Myanmar. 

The inaugural meeting of the Canada-China Joint Committee on Culture will be co-chaired by ministers from both countries in Ottawa in February 2018. This platform will provide an opportunity for high-level dialogue on matters of mutual interest in culture, creative industries, the arts, heritage, and other areas. 

Cooperation on the rule of law and labor is one of Canada's priorities in China. To further this goal, the Prime Minister announced $5 million to deepen judicial cooperation and an additional $1.5 million to support work on labor and employment issues.

The widespread belief that numerous individuals, who did not meet the $5,000 Canada Emergency Response Benefit (CERB) threshold, illegally received billions of dollars and are now refusing to repay it is an alarming notion. It is justified for the government to take action against these individuals. They took advantage of a hastily designed program that lacked sufficient safeguards while exploiting the generosity of the Canadian people. The program inadvertently incentivized individuals to cease employment and resist returning when their employers requested, and now they seek to retain funds they knowingly obtained while ineligible.

The reality is that pandemic relief programs, such as the CERB, were swiftly implemented with strong encouragement from the government to apply and ensure safety. The rules underwent multiple changes in the initial stages, and even now, conflicting legacy rules can be found online. Recipients of social assistance, constituting approximately 5% of Canada's population or 1 in 20 people, were frequently mandated by law to apply for the CERB and faced potential penalties and sanctions for non-compliance. Moreover, pandemic benefits were largely offset by reducing other benefits received.

Subsequently, stricter measures were implemented regarding pandemic benefits in the following ways: 

1. The $5,000 income threshold was limited to incomes specifically outlined in the legislation, which proved more restrictive than what was originally communicated on websites. For instance, honorariums were listed as qualifying income online but were not covered in the CERB legislation.

2. The $5,000 income had to be received, not merely earned. Many individuals worked but did not receive their pay due to business distress and closures caused by the pandemic. However, those who earned money but did not receive it retroactively became ineligible for the CERB. This rule seems illogical, as the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) typically does not accept any explanations for difficulties in obtaining documentation of earnings unless they are taken to tax court.

3. CERB claimants were retrospectively required by the tax court to provide meticulous bookkeeping records to prove their eligibility. Inability to produce detailed accounts often resulted in ineligibility.

4. Claimants who narrowly missed meeting the eligibility criteria faced sanctions. The rules allowed no exceptions or room for judges to determine eligibility, unlike most programs where exceptions are common. Exceptionality, which is typically present in various programs, is entirely absent in the case of pandemic benefits.

5. The norms surrounding hardship rules, which usually offer greater leeway for extended payment terms, have been significantly tightened.

6. The federal budget allocated over $50 million to pursue low-income individuals who were found ineligible for benefits, despite the plethora of contradictions in communication materials and administration. 

Unfortunately, the focus on these matters is overshadowing Canada's remarkable achievement of meeting its poverty goals nearly a decade ahead of schedule. Rather than celebrating this incredible accomplishment, some view it as an unsuccessful experiment in protecting our most vulnerable residents, which is an erroneous perception.

Working in open government involves the important task of actively listening to citizens and stakeholders. The Government of Canada recognizes the recurring theme that citizen engagement must be authentic and meaningful. To address this, we have developed a set of principles and guidelines to ensure transparency, relevance, inclusivity, accountability, and adaptability in our engagement on policy issues.

Our journey to these principles began with a large engagement process in 2013, wherein we sought input to support the development of Canada's second action plan on open government. Through conversations with Canadians, we identified concerns regarding meaningful engagement, which led us to commit to developing principles and standards for public consultations in collaboration with citizens and civil society.

To fulfill this commitment, we started by conducting an environmental scan to understand global practices. We then engaged with the federal government's regulatory community through workshops and discussed the issue with the academic community at a congress in June 2015. Subsequently, the Canadian Open Dialogue Forum became a platform where we collaborated with over 200 participants from civil society, government, academia, and business to co-create a set of principles during a two-day conference in March 2016.

Throughout this process, we had ongoing consultations, refining and editing the principles to ensure both the government and our community were satisfied. We acknowledge that we made mistakes along the way and needed to make adjustments, even after extensive discussions. For instance, at the GovMaker event in 2016, we proposed a principle stating that "participants should know what's on and off the table" to enhance relevance. However, we recognized the consensus in the room that if the process is truly "open," nothing should be entirely off the table. We also heard the need for co-creation of engagement processes and shared accountability, which we have incorporated into the principles.

The outcome of this endeavor is a set of principles that guide engagement between the government and citizens. We are currently experimenting with applying these principles to public consultations and developing more detailed guidance on their implementation. Furthermore, we are working towards using these principles as a basis for evaluating the effectiveness of various public engagement activities conducted by the Government of Canada. A significant focus of our efforts is strengthening relationships and engagement with Indigenous peoples and nations.

We invite you to stay tuned for a future blog post that will delve into measuring the effectiveness of these principles and exploring the relationship between engagement and trust in government. Thank you, and we are eager to continue learning together.

Thom Kearney and the Open Government Team

In my inaugural blog post, I am thrilled to share my broader reflections on the core work of the RDU (Results and Delivery Unit) and provide an overview of our role, goals, and day-to-day activities that go beyond our more visible work of tracking progress on mandate letter commitments and reporting on outcomes (more on those in my upcoming post).

Firstly, our primary focus is to prepare materials for the Prime Minister and the Cabinet Committee on Agenda, Results, and Communications. These materials, typically presented in the form of dashboards, heat maps, and concise progress reports, outline advancements made on key priorities and address areas that require attention. For instance, our reports have highlighted progress in gender-based budgeting and analysis across the system, as well as improved recruitment of underrepresented groups in Canada's uniformed and security agencies. However, they have also identified areas where further progress is needed. Conducting brief stock take meetings with the Prime Minister and key leaders, supported by data, has proven to be an effective way to expedite progress. Consequently, there is now enhanced clarity across the public service that the Prime Minister expects targets to be met, and rigorous gender-based analysis and budgeting are required for all new proposals. In practice, this means that proposals will undergo thorough assessments to evaluate their differential impact on various groups, such as women or racialized communities. We will soon finalize our approach to publicly sharing these reports on the results we produce for the Prime Minister.

Secondly, we provide assistance to departments as they develop new policy and program submissions. Our focus revolves around three fundamental questions: What are the intended outcomes? How will they be achieved? And how will progress be evaluated and adjustments made if necessary? Our role primarily involves providing guidance to departments on their submissions to the Cabinet, but it can also entail a more detailed examination of their programs. Recently, we have collaborated with departments to clarify their policy goals and evaluation strategies on various issues, including homelessness reduction, expanding broadband coverage in remote and rural communities, addressing the opioid crisis, improving job training program outcomes, and reducing the federal government's carbon footprint.

Thirdly, we closely collaborate with departments on a day-to-day basis to assist ministers in overcoming obstacles to the successful implementation of their initiatives within the system. Instead of allowing problems to persist, we bring them to light, direct them to the appropriate decision-making forums, and strive to expedite progress. In some cases, we conduct in-depth analyses of high-priority issues that are not progressing as expected. This involves examining the overall delivery chain and considering all partners and policies that may either aid or hinder successful implementation. Examples of such endeavors include exploring the complexities surrounding long-term boil water advisories on reserves. This multifaceted issue has proven challenging to resolve; therefore, a joint team composed of representatives from different departments, the PCO (Privy Council Office), and communities has been mapping out the delivery chain and identifying the underlying challenges.

Previously, these three functions were not systematically performed across the federal government. While they were occasionally undertaken in response to specific situations, they lacked a consistent and ongoing approach. All three functions are designed to support a larger objective – shifting the culture of the federal government towards a heightened focus on implementation issues and outcomes. This entails investing more in individuals capable of delivering programs and projects, as well as allocating additional resources to data collection and evaluation to determine the results being achieved. Therefore, "Results & Delivery" is not just the name of our unit – it encapsulates our mission each day. I suppose we are somewhat self-explanatory: an "autonym".

This blog will serve as a platform for me to describe our ongoing activities and discuss the challenges the public service encounters as we strive towards becoming a more outcomes-focused organization. In my next post, I will delve into our approach to public reporting and what lies ahead.

As the Chief Information Officer (CIO) for the Government of Canada, I am constantly pondering the future of governments in this era dominated by groundbreaking platforms like Uber, Airbnb, and Alibaba. This question is not only important to my role but also to the daily lives of all Canadian citizens. I recently addressed this question in an article titled "The Government of Canada's Information Technology Strategic Plan," published in the August 2017 edition of the Public Sector Digest.

Information should be available and utilized by third parties to deliver services to citizens on behalf of the government.

Unfortunately, the Government of Canada has operated in an environment where information is not released by default, partnerships are not easily formed, and linear approaches hinder our ability to serve citizens. That's why we released our Information Technology Strategic Plan for 2016-2020. It is a step towards adapting more quickly to rapid societal developments.

While we will continue to invest federal funding in areas like superclusters and artificial intelligence, we must capitalize on these investments sooner. We must also prioritize open government and service agendas to enable our government to function as a platform. In the article, I outlined some forward paths, including modernizing our engagement tools, building proper technology architecture, adopting innovative procurement approaches, and enhancing collaboration with partners. All of these efforts aim to create a more open government.

Most importantly, we must place people at the center of our efforts. We need a public service that embraces new approaches and empowers our employees to think digitally. This requires a fundamental change in our organization to adapt to both traditional needs and new realities. As the Government of Canada's CIO, I am excited to work with my team to modernize the public service technology landscape for the benefit of all Canadian citizens.

In 2015, the Canadian people elected our Liberal government with a mandate to enhance the clarity and consistency of government accounting processes. We are proud to report that we are fulfilling this commitment. It is crucial for Canadians, as well as their elected representatives, to have access to information regarding the allocation and use of public funds. Transparency in financial matters is fundamental to a healthy representative democracy. That is why our government has recently implemented significant changes to enhance the clarity, transparency, and accountability of government spending.

Traditionally, the government presents its spending plans for the upcoming year through the main estimates, which are tabled in Parliament. However, this process has led to confusion as initiatives announced in the federal budget were often excluded from the main estimates. To address this issue, we have reorganized the order of these documents. Now, the main estimates are presented after the budget, and we have included a budget implementation vote within the main estimates. This marks the first time in recent history that the main estimates, which I presented on April 16th, encompass 100% of the measures outlined in the budget for this year. This allows parliamentarians to have more accurate and detailed information, enabling them to hold the government accountable for its spending of taxpayer dollars. This represents a significant advancement in government accountability.

To achieve this, we have introduced a new centrally managed budget implementation vote in the main estimates. As per the law, the Treasury Board, the cabinet committee responsible for allocating funds to departments, can only assign these funds to specific new budget measures outlined in the budget's comprehensive list of funding for each spending initiative. Any other use of public funds would be unauthorized. Renowned economists Scott Clark and Peter Devries have given Budget 2018 an "A" grade for fiscal credibility, praising its transparency and detailed financial analysis. Auditor General Michael Ferguson has also emphasized the importance of adhering to the allocation of funds as specified in the budget.

We are providing Parliament with a clear breakdown of where the funding for the new budget implementation vote originates from within the budget and how it will be utilized. Parliamentarians can now directly trace the money from this central vote to a specific line in the budget and the main estimates, ensuring transparency and accountability. Additionally, to enhance clarity, we will include the allocations from Annex 1 of the main estimates directly in the supply bill, which will be voted on by Parliament this spring.

This heightened transparency is made possible by the unprecedented level of detail provided in the budget regarding new spending measures by each department. Furthermore, we will provide monthly online reports and supplementary estimates throughout the year to demonstrate precisely how the Treasury Board is allocating funds to departments for specific budget initiatives.

To illustrate the efficacy of this system, let us consider the new women entrepreneurship strategy, aimed at promoting the growth of women-owned businesses and job creation. Through our new monthly online reporting, Canadians can track the funds allocated to this strategy, categorized by federal agency, as we expand our support for women in business.

Throughout the process of reforming the estimates, I have actively engaged with my fellow parliamentarians in a transparent and constructive manner through multiple committee appearances. Thanks to these crucial changes, parliamentarians now possess greater oversight of government spending than ever before. I firmly believe that these reforms will result in a more transparent and accountable government that benefits all Canadians.

I have extensive experience teaching policy at various levels, including the community, to recipients of ODSP and OW, at foundations, for governments, agencies, and volunteers. In many of these settings, I have also instructed on benefit design and have even written a comprehensive guide on understanding benefit design and the ten principles of good benefit design.

Unfortunately, the CERB and CRB programs do not adhere to four of these ten principles. However, I do not place blame solely on the designers. It is nearly impossible to create such a large suite of programs without making some mistakes and taking shortcuts. Nevertheless, Canada was rightfully praised for the scale, efficiency, and speed at which it implemented its pandemic benefits.

When speed is of the essence, the principles of effective benefit delivery may not be the primary concern. However, as I mentioned earlier, two wrongs don't make a right. While errors may occur during the initial rollout, there is an opportunity to rectify them through appeals. This is exemplified by the government's actions in assisting students, the self-employed, and low-income seniors. These cases form the basis of my objections in this series.

Let's now examine the violations that occurred as the CERB and CRB programs were hastily implemented. The first principle I propose is aligning program objectives with the design. The primary objective of the pandemic benefits was to ensure people's safety by keeping them indoors during the early stages of the pandemic. Another objective was to assist individuals who lost their jobs and were unable to resume work. However, the CERB and CRB only provided benefits to those who earned at least $5,000 in 2019, which does not align with the first principle. Many people with lower earnings also experienced job loss and were forced to work during the most dangerous period of the pandemic. Furthermore, the $5,000 threshold was arbitrary and lacked a basis in Canadian values.

The second principle is aligning Canadian values with design parameters. I have yet to encounter a Canadian value that mandates restricting pandemic benefits to individuals who earned over $5,000. Canadians believe in supporting those who have lost their jobs, as evidenced by our existing employment insurance and welfare programs. Therefore, the second design principle is not met, primarily due to the arbitrary nature of the $5,000 threshold.

The third principle involves understanding benefit structure. The CERB and CRB demonstrated remarkable innovation, but it is challenging to determine if the benefits reached the intended recipients. The rules surrounding income eligibility changed after the benefits were implemented, causing confusion regarding what counted as income, who was eligible, when benefits were granted, and how they were distributed. However, it is difficult to argue that the CERB and CRB violated the principle of understanding benefit structure, as there was insufficient time to thoroughly study and refine it.

The fourth principle is perhaps the most crucial, which is understanding the four elements of an income test. In the case of the CERB and CRB, there is an absence of a recovery or tax-back rate on income. There is no gradual transition or exit strategy. Either an individual is eligible or they are not. Missing the threshold by even a cent renders one ineligible, while exceeding it by a cent makes them eligible. This lack of on and off ramps, even in a rushed design process, constitutes a violation of a fundamental principle.

In conclusion, while the CERB and CRB programs were implemented rapidly and achieved significant results, they do fall short in adhering to certain principles of good benefit design. Recognizing these violations will allow us to improve the future design and implementation of similar programs.

The Digital Transformation Office recently conducted a wayfinding research project to gain a better understanding of how individuals navigate different sections of the Government of Canada's web presence. We collaborated with Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada, Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada, Veterans Affairs Canada, and Statistics Canada to investigate their usage of the global theme and topic menu on Canada.ca. We discovered that some institutions found the menu insufficient for their complex navigation needs, which hindered their adoption of the Canada.ca design. To find a solution, we needed to explore navigation habits as a whole and develop a strategy to effectively meet user needs.

The wayfinding project consisted of a baseline study to identify and assess findability issues, as well as a comparison study to test potential solutions. Our findings influenced changes to the Canada.ca design. Through research and prototyping activities, we explored options to remove the menu while maintaining or enhancing the effectiveness of global navigation. It was also crucial for us to uphold the confidence and trust associated with the Canada.ca brand.

Our prototype incorporated the following design elements for testing purposes:
1. A global header without a menu
2. Theme links moved from the menu to the footer
3. Inclusion of a sign-in button in the global header
4. More prominent breadcrumb links
5. Implementation of a simplified theme page template

We applied the new design to pages already utilizing the Canada.ca design, as well as those that were not. Task success remained consistent, and there was even an improvement in navigating between themes. This consistency can be attributed to the fact that breadcrumbs are used more frequently than the global menu for navigation. When clear links to theme-level pages are provided in the breadcrumb, users can easily find their intended destination. Additionally, we discovered that people often use the menu to locate the sign-in page. Given that signing in is a top task on Canada.ca, we incorporated a contextual sign-in button on relevant pages, placed at the top-right below the global header, where users typically expect to find it. This implementation proved successful, as task success was maintained or improved during the comparison round of testing. For more detailed information, please refer to our research summary.

Given that Canada.ca is a website heavily relied upon by individuals on a daily basis, we are taking a transitional approach to minimize disruption for users while implementing these design improvements to our navigation. Some of the work has already been completed, and more is currently in progress. Here is our roll-out plan:

1. Updates to the Canada.ca homepage: Our analysis of footer usage patterns on the homepage versus other pages revealed that some footer links were heavily used on the homepage but rarely accessed elsewhere on the site. As a result, we have relocated these links from the footer to the content section of the homepage. This change increases their visibility where users actually engage with them and creates additional space in the footer for more suitable links.

2. Contextual sign-in button: The global header now includes a contextual sign-in button as an optional element. This button will be present on pages where users are likely seeking to sign in to their accounts. Our research indicated that many people used the global menu to access the sign-in page. By presenting a sign-in button in the top right of the content area, we make the sign-in process more prominent and easy to locate when signing in is a top task. As users become accustomed to seeing and using the sign-in button consistently below the header, they will rely less on the menu to access and sign in to their accounts.

"Designing with users is an essential aspect of the Government of Canada's digital standards. However, it can be challenging to prioritize user-centric design when faced with tight deadlines and financial constraints. Building digital services that truly meet user needs requires a thorough understanding of who our users are, their needs, and the impact our services have on their lives.

One valuable resource in gaining insights from various user groups is our call centers. Whether they are in-house or outsourced, call center agents have access to a wealth of customer feedback, including complaints, grievances, praise, and product insights. Leveraging this data allows us to improve our web content and services while keeping real people in mind.

To illustrate the impact of collaborating with call center staff, let's consider how their input helped us make swift content improvements for better service delivery on Canada.ca. In March 2020, our call centers experienced a significant surge in calls and emails related to employment insurance (EI) and the Canada Emergency Response Benefit (CERB). The overwhelming call volumes at the government's main 1-800 O Canada number and Service Canada's email system made headlines, causing concern among Canadians who had to wait for hours to receive assistance.

To address this issue, Service Canada sought assistance from the Digital Transformation Office (DTO) to enhance their phone and email contact pages. The goal was to encourage more self-service behavior among visitors to the website, building on our success in improving contact pages for the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) to reduce call volumes.

To assess the impact of our interventions, we used web analytics and call volumes in early April 2020 as a baseline measurement. At that time, call wait times exceeded several hours, and many individuals were unable to connect. Additionally, email response times were delayed beyond the standard 48-hour window, and the Public Health Agency's call center was redirecting hundreds of calls daily concerning CERB and EI topics.

Based on user behavior, we hypothesized that visitors to the contact page were not reading the lengthy alert at the top and were reluctant to explore other pages for answers. This was likely because they had already decided to seek direct contact. To address this, we prototyped and tested two ideas. Firstly, we implemented a smaller alert banner at the top of the page, consisting of a concise sentence encouraging users to search for answers on the page before calling. Secondly, we placed answers to frequently asked questions at the top of the page using the expand/collapse pattern, allowing users to access specific answers without leaving the page.

Testing these solutions yielded positive results. Users actively looked for answers on the page and successfully found them. By implementing a shorter and more user-friendly design, we were able to provide the most relevant content while maintaining a simple and streamlined page layout."
