After working in the field of aesthetics for over 25 years, I have had the opportunity to treat numerous skin conditions, including the common complaint of melasma. Originating from the Greek language, the term "melasma" loosely translates to "black spot," reflecting the stubborn nature of this condition. Melasma typically appears on the forehead, cheeks, and upper lip, setting it apart from other forms of hyperpigmentation. What makes it particularly challenging to successfully treat is that it is not only worsened by exposure to ultraviolet light, but it is also hormonally-induced.

Who is at risk of developing melasma? While melasma can affect up to 33% of the population, women are at a significantly higher risk than men, with men accounting for only 10% of the affected population. Approximately 15% to 50% of pregnant women experience melasma, commonly known as "pregnancy mask," which typically fades after giving birth. Melasma is most prevalent during a woman's reproductive years, typically appearing between the ages of 20 and 40. The use of oral contraceptives can also increase the risk of melasma due to the elevated levels of estrogen and progesterone, which are believed to contribute to the condition. Individuals with darker skin tones are also more susceptible to melasma due to higher melanin levels. Moreover, those with hypothyroidism face an increased risk due to hormonal imbalances caused by an underactive thyroid.

Why does melasma seem to fade and reappear? Those who have witnessed their melasma improve, only to have it resurface, understand the frustration of managing this condition. Given the multitude of contributing factors and the significant influence of hormonal fluctuations, it is notoriously challenging to control and maintain. While melasma can occur throughout the year, most individuals experience a resurgence in the summer months when heat and sunlight exacerbate the condition. Conversely, they may observe fading in the winter months. Regardless of the season or weather, it is vital to wear broad-spectrum SPF daily to minimize the harmful effects of UV radiation.

Is there anything else one can do to improve melasma besides using SPF? As we bid farewell to the last days of summer and approach the holiday season, many individuals are considering laser treatments to fade melasma and enhance their overall complexion. The Lutronic Hollywood Spectra is the first short-pulse laser to receive FDA clearance for melasma treatment and is suitable for all skin types. Alongside visible improvement in melasma, a series of Hollywood Spectra treatments will leave your skin looking brighter and clearer, reducing the appearance of fine lines and wrinkles thanks to its collagen-stimulating properties.

If you are grappling with melasma, it is important to remember that you are not alone. Although there is no cure, this condition is treatable and manageable.

The Canadian government has demonstrated its strong support for nuclear power in its clean energy strategy through the announcement of the federal budget for 2023. This budget emphasizes the importance of nuclear power in achieving the country's clean energy goals and ensuring energy security. In addition to being included in the clean energy investment tax credit, nuclear power is now eligible for various other tax incentives, creating a level playing field for clean energy technologies and allowing nuclear power to compete fairly with other non-emitting sources of power.

John Gorman, President and CEO of the Canadian Nuclear Association, stated that today's budget signifies a significant shift in the government's approach to nuclear power. Nuclear power is no longer merely considered an option, but rather a fundamental and necessary component of Canada's low-carbon energy system. The budget introduces a new 15% refundable investment tax credit for clean electricity, which applies to all sizes of nuclear power projects, including small modular reactors (SMRs), large builds, and refurbishment projects. This tax credit is available to both public and privately owned entities, addressing concerns raised by the Canadian Nuclear Association regarding the applicability of tax credits to crown corporations. The credit also extends to equipment involved in the transmission of electricity between provinces and territories.

It is important to note that this investment tax credit is separate from the clean technology investment tax credit introduced in the 2022 federal budget. The clean technology investment tax credit offers a tax credit of up to 30% for non-emitting electricity generation technologies, including SMRs.

Furthermore, today's budget introduces a 30% investment tax credit for clean technology manufacturing, which encompasses the manufacturing of clean technologies as well as the extraction, processing, or recycling of critical minerals. This credit also includes the manufacturing of nuclear energy equipment and the processing or recycling of nuclear fuels.

The government's support for nuclear power is further demonstrated through various other measures. These include the extension of the reduced tax rate for zero-emission technology manufacturers to include the nuclear power sector, additional funding of $20 billion for the Canada Infrastructure Bank to accelerate the energy transition and invest in clean power and green infrastructure, an increased budget of $1.3 billion to streamline regulatory reviews and approvals, and partnerships with the public sector pension investment board through the Canada Growth Fund to attract private capital to Canada's clean economy. Additionally, the budget allocates $500 million over ten years to the Strategic Innovation Fund, which has previously supported SMR projects by companies such as Moltex, Westinghouse, and Terrestrial Energy.

The budget also supports initiatives aimed at accelerating Canada's clean energy transition, particularly through the electrification of sectors currently reliant on fossil fuels, such as transportation, buildings, industry, and the production of hydrogen.

Today's budget aligns with recent joint statements between Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and US President Joe Biden, as well as the collaboration between Natural Resources Canada and the US Department of Energy. These joint statements recognized the crucial role of nuclear power in the global energy transition and emphasized the need for cooperation in clean energy opportunities and supply chains, including advanced and conventional nuclear energy. Today's budget solidifies these statements by outlining policies that foster cross-border cooperation and move towards an integrated and mutually beneficial North American nuclear ecosystem.

The Canadian nuclear industry welcomes the government's commitment to nuclear power playing an increasingly significant role in the country's energy mix. While more steps are necessary to ensure equal treatment for all clean energy technologies, today's budget represents a significant stride towards maintaining Canada's position as a global leader in clean energy technology advancement.

Climate change poses a significant challenge in the 21st century, and nuclear power stands as a viable solution to address this issue. As the only expandable, low-carbon energy source that can offer reliable and affordable electricity, nuclear power is well-equipped to meet our climate goals.

To combat climate change, it is crucial for humanity to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, particularly carbon dioxide, which has a carbon budget limit. In order to have a 50% chance of keeping global warming below 1.5°C, we can emit up to 580 gigatonnes more of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. However, the burning of fossil fuels currently results in approximately 37 gigatonnes per year. We must act quickly to increase our supply of carbon-free energy, including nuclear, solar, and wind power.

Under the Paris Agreement, countries worldwide have committed to limiting their total carbon emissions, which should help us stay within the carbon budget. However, some countries are struggling to meet these commitments. For example, Germany had to increase its fossil fuel use due to the closure of nuclear power plants, and China is significantly expanding its coal-fired electricity generation. Even Canada is not on track to achieve its target of reducing carbon emissions by 30% between 2005 and 2030.

To stay within the carbon budget, there are three main strategies to pursue. The first is reducing energy consumption, which has seen some success. The second is carbon capture, exemplified by ongoing efforts in Weyburn, Saskatchewan. However, neither of these strategies alone can lead us to a carbon-neutral future. We must also prioritize greening our energy mix, maximizing energy efficiency, and capturing carbon dioxide. Replacing fossil fuels with low- and zero-emission energy sources is crucial.

Solar, wind, and tidal power have made significant progress in the past decade, reducing prices. However, they still account for only two percent of Canada's total power generation. Hydroelectric power is a zero-emission option that Canada has extensively utilized, but it is limited to specific geographic locations and has almost reached its maximum capacity at 90%. On the other hand, nuclear power produces no greenhouse gas emissions during operation, requires less land than hydroelectric power or renewable sources, and Canada has an abundant supply of uranium. There are numerous potential sites for nuclear power plants, making it a promising tool in the fight against climate change.

To assess carbon emissions accurately, it is essential to consider the entire life cycle, including construction, supply chain, operation, decommissioning, and disposal. When all these factors are taken into account, nuclear power compares favorably to renewable energy sources and outperforms fossil fuels. According to the World Nuclear Association, the world's 445 reactors save 2.5 gigatonnes of carbon dioxide emissions annually. Future reactors have the potential to save even more.

The success of utilizing nuclear power to transition to greener electricity grids can be seen in Ontario, Canada. Until the 1990s, the province relied heavily on coal for electricity, resulting in significant emissions. However, with the presence of 18 nuclear power reactors, Ontario was able to eliminate coal from its energy mix by 2014. This transition not only improved air quality but also significantly reduced carbon emissions. Despite a 30% population growth since 1990, emissions in the province were 161 megatonnes in 2016, according to the Ontario Auditor General.

The Canadian Trucking Alliance (CTA) commends the recent introduction of the Recognized Employer Pilot (REP), which aims to address labor shortages and protect workers, including temporary foreign workers (TFW), from workplace exploitation. However, the CTA urges the Canadian government to take further action, specifically targeting employers in the trucking sector who engage in the deceptive practice known as "driver inc," which denies truck drivers their rights under the labor code.

The three-year pilot program, announced by Minister Randy Boissonnault, will commence in September. The CTA, which has advocated for a similar shift in the TFW program, sees the REP as a positive step towards addressing labor shortages and reducing administrative burdens for recognized employers. However, the success of the pilot in safeguarding foreign workers in the trucking sector depends on the criteria for becoming a recognized employer and must be supported by a thorough audit and oversight system to ensure desired outcomes.

Stephen Laskowski, President of the CTA, emphasizes the labor shortage in the trucking industry and the need to recruit more Canadian and foreign workers. He believes that the announcement will help stabilize distribution networks in various sectors of the domestic economy. Laskowski also stresses the importance of restricting access to foreign labor through the TFW program or other immigration programs to recognized employers that strictly adhere to labor compliance. To establish the credibility and effectiveness of the program, the Canadian government must implement a robust auditing system to ensure compliance with the law and protect workers from scams like "driver inc."

Calgary, AB - The Canadian Cattle Association (CCA) is delighted to announce that Wray Ranch, located near Irricana, Alberta, has been awarded the Environmental Stewardship Award (TESA) for 2023. Doug and Linda Wray, in partnership with their nephew Tim Wray and his wife Joanne, are being recognized for their commitment to sustainable practices that promote soil health and reduce erosion.

In 1998, Wray Ranch underwent a significant transformation, converting 1,000 acres of cropland into high-legume perennial pasture, enabling year-round grazing. The Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) presents an exciting opportunity for Canada's climate and energy security. Canada possesses the necessary resources and expertise to become a global leader in low-carbon transportation fuels, with robust energy infrastructure and sustainable feedstocks. However, our competitive investment climate lags behind that of the United States, with which we compete for investment in the North American fuels market.

Over the past two decades, the US has implemented successful programs, including tax credits, to attract investment in clean fuels. As a result, they have developed a strong capacity for clean fuels production, while Canada has become increasingly reliant on clean fuel imports. Members of the Canadian Fuels Association (CFA) are currently among the largest producers of clean fuels, and since 2020, they have remained committed to producing more clean fuels within Canada.

However, the US IRA, introduced last summer, has changed the game by offering generous production tax credits (PTC) for low-carbon transportation fuels and sustainable aviation fuel. This PTC has significantly tilted project economics in favor of clean fuel projects in the US. Unfortunately, this development threatens to result in the export of Canadian-grown feedstocks to the US, leading to significant economic losses for Canada and undermining our energy self-sufficiency.

This situation is particularly concerning as CFA members have planned large-scale renewable diesel, sustainable aviation fuel, hydrogen, and ethanol projects, worth $8 billion, with the potential to deliver 10 million metric tons of greenhouse gas reductions across the country. However, these projects are now at risk of being delayed or relocated to the US due to the lack of investment parity.

Parkland's recent decision to discontinue plans for a renewable diesel facility in Burnaby, BC, citing the IRA as a key factor, highlights the urgency for a response from the Canadian government. Therefore, we call for the introduction of a clean fuel production tax credit in Budget 2023. This credit would apply to all clean fuels produced in Canada, including ethanol, renewable diesel, sustainable aviation fuel, and hydrogen, providing the necessary investment certainty. Similar to the US, the credit rate would vary based on carbon intensity, incentivizing greater greenhouse gas reductions.

Implementing a clean fuel production tax credit would yield economic and climate benefits throughout the value chain, from feedstock providers to distribution, while reducing our dependence on imports and creating numerous direct and indirect jobs for Canadians. We cannot risk losing these additional economic and climate benefits for Canada.

As Environment and Climate Change Minister Stephen Guilbeault recently stated, the Inflation Reduction Act has made innovation in clean tech more competitive than ever, leaving no room to stick with the status quo. Canada's transportation energy sector has played a vital role in our economic success for over a century. We now have a unique opportunity to become a global leader in clean fuel production while meeting the evolving energy needs and climate goals of Canadians.

Budget 2023 is a critical juncture. We must respond to the IRA or risk being left behind, jeopardizing our economy, energy security, and climate goals.

It will also expand Matalco's service offering to a broader customer base and ensure access to low-carbon primary metal for its operations. By 2028, more than half of the United States' aluminium demand is projected to come from recycled sources.

Rio Tinto's CEO, Jakob Stausholm, expressed excitement about investing in recycling and delivering low-carbon materials, stating that it is a natural extension of their industry-leading primary aluminium business. Chris Galifi, CEO of Giampaolo Group, highlighted the companies' shared commitment to a circular economy and their complementary expertise in the recycling value chain.

The transaction is subject to regulatory approvals and is expected to be completed in the first half of 2024.

Rio Tinto is also collaborating with the governments of Canada and Quebec to deploy the Elysis zero-carbon aluminium smelting technology at their Saguenay–Lac-Saint-Jean facilities. The Aluminium Stewardship Initiative (ASI) recently held its second Annual General Meeting (AGM) in Montreal, marking a significant step forward in the responsible production, sourcing, and stewardship of aluminium. The AGM brought together over 80 representatives from various stakeholders, including aluminium producers, users, civil society, associations, and government officials. Supported by the Government of Quebec, Rio Tinto, and the Aluminium Association of Canada, the event featured formal AGM proceedings and a public program with distinguished keynote speakers.

During the event, keynote speakers Steven Guilbeault, Chris Coulter, and Michael Liebreich addressed the challenges that initiatives like ASI face in gaining acceptance and implementing successful programs. They also discussed future trends, particularly in energy, that could inspire the development and improve the relevance of ASI's standards program. Furthermore, ASI directors engaged in a panel discussion to explore the organization's strategic direction and what success would look like from different stakeholder perspectives. Representatives from civil society, industrial users, and upstream producers highlighted the expected benefits of ASI's standards to their respective sectors after five years of implementation.

Dr. Fiona Solomon, CEO of ASI, provided an overview of the organization's program design and delivery, emphasizing its contribution to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). ASI's standards address a wide range of SDGs, including responsible consumption and production, partnerships for the goals, and more.

The AGM included two parallel streams in the afternoon, offering insights into ASI's standards and intended impacts. One stream provided an overview of ASI's program, while a panel of ASI members shared their perspectives on the program's potential. They highlighted how ASI can enable responsible growth in the production, transformation, and use of aluminium, fostering economic, social, and environmental benefits. National aluminium associations expressed their desire to support local aluminium ecosystems during the implementation phase, ensuring proper membership alignment, policy coherence, and assistance to downstream businesses in their respective regions.

The second parallel stream delved into the results and feedback from previous consultations on ASI's standards and assurance model. Attendees also had the opportunity to enjoy a local treat of snow with locally tapped maple syrup at an on-site "urban sugar shack." The day concluded with a cocktail reception attended by VIP guests from the Government of Quebec and representatives from the Consulate General of Britain, Russia, and France.

The AGM event marks a significant milestone in ASI's activities throughout 2017 as it finalizes the development of its program. A final public comment period on the draft standards will take place from May to June, followed by a pilot testing period with members via a custom assurance platform from July to September. These inputs will be crucial in creating a robust and credible standards and assurance model for the aluminium value chain. ASI has confirmed that it remains on track to launch its independent third-party certification program at the end of the year.

Canada Post has announced the launch of its first depot utilizing battery-electric corporate delivery vehicles in Nanaimo, B.C. The Nanaimo depot will employ 14 fully electric cargo vans for collection and delivery services, replacing traditional internal combustion vehicles.

Aligned with Canada Post's goal to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050, the company has pledged to electrify 50% of its national fleet, consisting of approximately 14,000 vehicles, by 2030. By 2040, the entire fleet will be fully electric. President and CEO of Canada Post, Doug Ettinger, and Chair of the Board of Directors, Suromitra Sanatani, were present at the depot's official launch to announce the introduction of these electric delivery vehicles.

Canada Post's commitment to sustainable delivery extends beyond fleet electrification. The company has adopted science-based targets to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. It is retrofitting existing facilities, constructing new net-zero carbon buildings, and sourcing renewable energy for its real estate and operations. Having already experimented with electric and low-emission vehicles over the years, Canada Post is now in the preliminary stages of fleet electrification. The corporation is introducing electric vehicles at select plants and depots to assess the most suitable equipment, charging infrastructure, and operational approaches. Canada Post's introduction of battery-electric corporate delivery vehicles in Nanaimo represents a significant step towards achieving its sustainability goals. By prioritizing electrification, investing in green infrastructure, and exploring innovative delivery options, Canada Post is paving the way for a stronger, greener Canada.

The World Health Organization (WHO) has launched an alert emphasizing the urgent need for increased investment in healthcare services in Afghanistan. The country's healthcare infrastructure is severely under-resourced, particularly in underserved areas, which are vulnerable due to the ongoing humanitarian crisis. Afghanistan has faced decades of instability, including severe droughts and natural disasters. As a result, millions of people lack access to healthcare and proper nutrition, placing them at risk of malnutrition and disease outbreaks. The situation is especially dire for women and girls, who face additional obstacles to healthcare due to education and workforce restrictions.

The revised Afghanistan Humanitarian Response Plan for 2023 reveals a concerning increase in the number of people in need of aid, with 28.8 million individuals requiring immediate assistance compared to 18.4 million in August 2021. The plan aims to provide health assistance to 14 million people, including 7.5 million children and 3.1 million women. While progress has been made in reaching 8.4 million individuals in the first half of 2023 and providing a total of 25.7 million healthcare services between 2022 and 2023, insufficient funding threatens to cut off essential health assistance to 8 million people. Additionally, 450,000 patients may lose access to life-saving trauma care services, and 1.6 million individuals with mental health conditions may lack necessary consultation and support.

The WHO's alert highlights the dire consequences of continued underfunding for Afghanistan's healthcare system. Barriers to delivering comprehensive services, especially for women and children, pose a significant challenge and increase vulnerability, particularly in underserved areas. Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, WHO Director-General, emphasizes the gravity of the situation, as the lack of resources and funding endangers countless lives, with women and children suffering the most. He calls on donors to generously support life-saving work.

Dr. Ahmed Al-Mandhari, WHO Regional Director for the Eastern Mediterranean, urges the international community to unite with the WHO in addressing the ongoing humanitarian health crisis in Afghanistan. He stresses the collective responsibility to act now and warns of catastrophic consequences if no action is taken. The inaugural World Health Organization (WHO) Traditional Medicine Global Summit 2023 concluded on August 18th, with a strong commitment from a diverse range of partners and stakeholders to promote evidence-based traditional, complementary, and integrative medicine (TCIM). The aim is to enhance progress towards universal health coverage and the Sustainable Development Goals by 2030, with the goal of improving the health and well-being of individuals and the planet.

The summit, held in Gandhinagar, Gujarat, India on August 17th and 18th, saw participation from health ministers of G20 and other countries, scientists, traditional medicine practitioners, healthcare workers, and civil society members from 88 countries. It provided a platform for all stakeholders to share their unique experiences, best practices, and ideas for collaboration. Indigenous groups from various regions, such as Australia, Bolivia, Brazil, Canada, Guatemala, and New Zealand, were also represented, recognizing the significant role TCIM plays in healthcare, culture, and livelihoods.

Preliminary findings from the WHO Global Survey on Traditional Medicine 2023, presented at the summit, revealed that approximately 100 countries have national policies and strategies related to TCIM. In many WHO member states, TCIM treatments are included in essential medicine lists, essential health service packages, and are covered by national health insurance schemes. A large majority of people seek TCIM interventions for the treatment, prevention, and management of noncommunicable diseases, palliative care, and rehabilitation.

Dr. Bruce Aylward, Assistant Director-General for Universal Health Coverage and Life Course at WHO, emphasized the importance of building a stronger evidence base to enable countries to develop appropriate regulations and policies surrounding TCIM. The summit also highlighted the potential of artificial intelligence in analyzing complex data on traditional medicine to identify promising practices for further scientific evaluation. This evidence, with ethical and equity safeguards, can then be translated into policies that facilitate the safe and effective integration of traditional medicine into healthcare systems.

In closing, Dr. Hans Kluge, WHO Regional Director for Europe, stated that the summit has challenged the status quo that has long separated different approaches to medicine and health. By breaking down silos, the aim is to collaborate more effectively and integrate TCIM into primary healthcare and universal health coverage. He emphasized the need for better evidence on the effectiveness, safety, and quality of traditional and complementary medicine through innovative methodologies for assessing and evaluating outcomes.

Dr. Shyama Kuruvilla, Senior Strategic Advisor and Lead for the WHO Traditional Medicine Global Center, who played a key role in organizing the summit, acknowledged the existing policies, tools, and practices, but noted the long journey ahead in fully harnessing TCIM approaches to improve health and well-being in harmony with the environment.

The summit's summary document includes conclusions and commitments from participants on a wide range of topics, including global policy, leadership, innovation, health workforce, data, evidence, monitoring, regulation, legal frameworks, and the preservation of biodiversity and sustainable development.

The GIDH, also referred to as "Guide," will be managed by WHO and serve as a network and platform to support the implementation of the Global Strategy on Digital Health 2020-2025. WHO will act as the secretariat for the strategy, working to bring together global standards, best practices, and resources to expedite the transformation of digital health systems.

Investing in global health has become a shared objective among world leaders. In 2015, they made a commitment to provide health services for all people by 2030. However, as we approach 2023, we are only halfway towards meeting the target set by the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) of achieving universal health coverage. It is clear that more effort, from implementation to investment in health, is needed to reach this globally agreed goal.

Before the COVID-19 pandemic, the World Health Organization estimated that low- and middle-income countries would need to significantly increase their health spending to achieve the health-related SDGs. This would require an additional $371 billion annually by 2030. This funding would not only improve access to health services but also contribute to building new facilities and training and placing health workers where they are needed. 

In addition to the pre-existing challenges, recent disruptions to health services caused by conflict, climate change, and economic instability have further increased the need for additional funding to achieve universal health coverage. Furthermore, preparing for future pandemics would require a massive investment of approximately $31.1 billion annually, with approximately one-third of that amount coming from international financing.

Temporary increases in government spending driven by the pandemic response led to a rise in global health spending, reaching approximately $9 trillion in 2020, which is nearly 11% of the gross domestic product. Public spending accounted for about 63% of this amount. However, it will be challenging for countries to find the necessary funds to meet the ambitious goal of universal health coverage, especially as national budgets are strained due to the economic impact of the pandemic.

To address this challenge, new sources of funding and innovative products that can mobilize the resources of the private sector are needed. It is clear that individual countries cannot solve the health care conundrum on their own; global solidarity and collective efforts are necessary. In light of this, the African Development Bank, the European Investment Bank, the Islamic Development Bank, and the World Health Organization are launching a new investment platform. This platform aims to mobilize impactful and coherent investments in primary health care (PHC) systems in individual countries to improve their resilience. Resources from partners like the European Commission are being channeled to remove investment risks and make the conditions highly attractive for beneficiary countries. The inter-American Development Bank is also considering joining this partnership to extend the initiative to the Latin American and Caribbean region.

The focus on primary health care is crucial because approximately 90% of essential health services can be delivered through quality primary health care. By bringing health professionals, doctors, and nurses closer to communities in local clinics, primary health care promotes health, prevents diseases, and reduces the need for costly secondary and tertiary services. It ensures that even the most rural and remote locations have access to essential health services and plays a vital role in a country's overall health system.

The COVID-19 pandemic and the resulting economic crisis have taught us the importance of investing in health services that can reach all individuals. It has revealed that health services are central to national security, development, and prosperity. Solidarity and equity must be integral parts of any health service solution. Cooperation between multilateral organizations and development banks is crucial in addressing these challenges.

We will focus on driving measurable impact in people's health outcomes by using innovative finance mechanisms to encourage domestic funding and contribute to our shared goal of health for all, without burdening countries with unsustainable debt. The launch of this new investment platform will take place in Paris at the Summit on a New Global Financing Pact, which will be held on June 22-23, 2023. At this summit, we will call for the generation of necessary finances to fight inequalities in health and other areas and to accelerate progress on the Sustainable Development Goals, including the climate transition.

Good health and well-being are goals shared by the entire world. However, achieving these goals will require collaboration between countries and institutions. As we strengthen our cooperation, we firmly believe that collaboration between nations and between governments and the private sector is critical to achieving universal health coverage. We invite our partners to join us in this global investment platform.

The "One Life, One Liver" campaign was launched on World Hepatitis Day, July 28, 2023. The campaign aims to raise awareness about the importance of testing and treatment for viral hepatitis, as the disease has the potential to surpass malaria, tuberculosis, and HIV in terms of fatalities by 2040 if current infection rates continue. Hepatitis causes liver damage and cancer, resulting in over a million deaths each year.

Among the five types of hepatitis infections, hepatitis B and C are responsible for the majority of cases and deaths. While hepatitis C can be cured, only 21% of those infected have been diagnosed and merely 13% have received curative treatment. Similarly, only 10% of people living with chronic hepatitis B are diagnosed, and a mere 2% of those infected are receiving life-saving medication.

Under the theme of "One Life, One Liver," the World Health Organization's World Hepatitis Day campaign emphasizes the significance of safeguarding the liver against hepatitis for a prolonged and healthy life. Maintaining good liver health also benefits other vital organs such as the heart, brain, and kidneys, which rely on the liver's proper functioning.

Despite the availability of better tools than ever to prevent, diagnose, and treat hepatitis, millions of people worldwide are living with undiagnosed and untreated cases. Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the Director-General of the WHO, highlights the organization's commitment to supporting countries in expanding the utilization of these tools, including cost-effective curative medications, to save lives and eradicate hepatitis.

The WHO will provide new guidance to track countries' progress towards eliminating hepatitis by 2030. To reduce new infections and deaths from hepatitis B and C, countries must ensure access to treatment for all pregnant women with hepatitis B, provide hepatitis B vaccines for newborns, diagnose 90% of people with hepatitis B and/or C, and offer treatment to 80% of all diagnosed individuals. Additionally, countries must prioritize optimal blood transfusion, safe injections, and harm reduction practices.

Vaccination, testing, and treatment are vital opportunities to protect the liver from hepatitis. The reduction of hepatitis B infections in children through vaccination is a crucial intervention in limiting overall viral hepatitis infections. The target for hepatitis B incidence is the only Sustainable Development Goals' (SDG) health target that was achieved in 2020 and is on track for 2030. However, many African countries still lack access to birth dose hepatitis B vaccines. Gavi's recent restart of its vaccine investment strategy, which includes the birth dose hepatitis B vaccine, will kickstart vaccination programs for newborns in West and Central Africa, where mother-to-child hepatitis B transmission rates remain high.

To eliminate mother-to-child transmission, the WHO recommends testing all pregnant women for hepatitis B during their pregnancy. If positive, they should receive treatment, and vaccines should be provided to their newborns. However, a recent WHO report reveals that out of the 64 countries with a policy, only 32 have implemented activities to screen for and manage hepatitis B in antenatal clinics. Similarly, 80% of the 103 countries surveyed have policies in place to screen and manage hepatitis B in HIV clinics, with 65% doing the same for hepatitis C. Enhancing hepatitis testing and treatment within HIV programs will protect people living with HIV from developing liver cirrhosis and cancer.

Although treatment rates for hepatitis C have been increasing for years, the progress in accessing curative treatment is now slowing down. Goal of the month: Decent work and economic growth

Sustainable Development Goal 8 aims to promote inclusive and sustainable economic growth, employment, and decent work for all. Unfortunately, the COVID-19 pandemic has caused a severe economic crisis, undoing progress towards ensuring decent work for everyone. Although global economies have shown signs of recovery since 2021, the improvement in employment opportunities remains challenging and fragile. 

As we reach the midpoint-review of the 2030 agenda, it is evident that multiple crises are putting immense pressure on the 17 Sustainable Development Goals. According to the 2023 UN World Economic Situations and Prospect Report (WESP), the growth momentum in the United States, European Union, and other developed economies has weakened, causing ripple effects worldwide. The projected world output growth is expected to decelerate from an estimated 3.0% in 2022 to 1.9% in 2023, marking one of the slowest rates in recent decades. 

Growth in real GDP per capita, which averaged 1.8% from 2015 to 2019, experienced a sharp decline of 4.1% in 2020. While it slowly increased by 5.2% in 2022, the growth in 2023 is estimated to be slower, falling short of the SDG target of 7%. The global employment opportunities have also been significantly impacted, particularly for women and youth. The UN Secretary General's 2023 SDGs report emphasizes a significant decline in unemployment rates in 2022, resulting in a total global unemployment estimate of 192 million. However, job recovery in developing countries has been slower, with rates higher than pre-pandemic levels.

Additional challenges, such as the impacts of climate change, have also hindered countries' efforts to achieve productive employment and decent work for all. To address these issues, it is crucial to focus on implementing a financial system that not only addresses rising debt and economic uncertainty but also promotes equitable pay and decent work opportunities for young people. This is especially important considering the disproportionate effects of the pandemic on women and young individuals in the labor market. While some recovery has been observed, young people aged 15-24 still face difficulties in finding decent employment. Furthermore, many young individuals, particularly young women, were not in education, employment, or training in 2022, particularly in regions such as Central, Southern, and Western Asia, and Northern Africa.

Ensuring the achievement of SDG 8 requires a comprehensive approach that addresses financial challenges, promotes economic stability, and focuses on providing equitable opportunities for all young people to secure decent work.

Tracking global financial stability risks from higher interest rates, our financial sector assessments are evaluating the impact of elevated borrowing costs and the possibility that central banks may maintain higher policy rates for longer than anticipated. On August 8, 2023, interest rate hikes implemented by global central banks to combat the largest inflation outbreak in four decades placed strain on banks in the United States and Europe. While rate hikes typically benefit lenders by increasing lending revenues, this time was different. Some banks suffered losses on bond holdings, including safe US treasuries, which caused concern among customers who swiftly withdrew their funds. This issue was magnified by technological advancements and social media. As a result, several banks experienced failures.

Our financial sector assessment program is a crucial component of our surveillance efforts, closely monitoring financial stability risks within individual countries and assessing their resilience. We also evaluate the adherence of financial sector supervision, regulation, crisis management tools, and safety nets, such as emergency liquidity support and deposit insurance, to international best practices. In addition, our program conducts stress tests to identify potential risks to banks and has recently enhanced risk assessments for nonbank financial intermediaries, including pension managers, insurers, and asset managers.

Our work is conducted against the backdrop of ongoing central bank interest rate increases and the potential for borrowing costs to remain elevated for longer than anticipated by investors, businesses, and households. This situation has the potential to increase financial stability risks and dampen economic growth, as we highlighted in July. The tightening of monetary policy could also lead to market volatility and rapid changes in bond and interest-rate derivatives markets. Even safe US treasury securities could experience a decline in value, possibly up to 30%, when yields rise by 400 basis points—an actual shock that has occurred since 2020 in 10-year treasury note yields.

Prior to March, our focus was primarily on the risks posed to nonbank financial institutions from shifts in bond markets. Many of these institutions have substantial investments in bonds and are vulnerable to valuation losses. Investment funds, in particular, may face rapid redemptions as customers swiftly withdraw from unprofitable funds. While pension and life insurance companies are less prone to runs due to penalties associated with early withdrawal, companies that employ derivatives and other complex transactions to enhance returns may face margin calls if the value of these instruments decreases. This was exemplified by some UK pension funds last year.

The events in March served as a reminder of the importance of bank runs. Regulatory reforms implemented after the global financial crisis aimed to enhance the resilience of banks by increasing their cash and bond holdings. Additionally, many countries established mechanisms for banks to borrow more easily from central banks to avoid selling bonds during periods of declining markets. However, in the case of Silicon Valley Bank, these safeguards did not effectively mitigate the impact of rapid monetary tightening. The value of the bank's bond holdings decreased, which affected its earnings, capital, and cash buffers. Depositors observed these strains and withdrew their funds. Unfortunately, the bank was not adequately prepared to access central bank liquidity in a timely manner and subsequently failed, along with other US lenders.

Inflation poses a significant risk to financial markets, prompting central banks to consider keeping interest rates higher for a longer period. This cautious approach is driven by investors' optimistic view of low inflation and the anticipation of a soft landing. However, this strategy could introduce financial stability risks and hinder economic growth.

In July 27, 2023, overall inflation in the United States and the Euro area has significantly decreased due to notable declines in energy and food prices. Year-on-year headline inflation currently stands at around 3 percent in the United States and below 5.5 percent in the Euro area. However, core inflation, which excludes food and energy prices, has declined at a slower pace, particularly in services inflation.

Market expectations suggest that headline inflation will continue to decline rapidly in the coming quarters, although some participants still foresee potential risks leading to higher inflation. This sentiment may be influenced by recent stickiness in core inflation. Market pricing data reveals that such upside risks are particularly prominent in Europe, where investors assign similar probabilities to inflation reaching the European Central Bank's 2 percent target or remaining around 4 percent. In the United States, investors appear to anticipate inflation above the target at around 3 percent.

Despite ongoing monetary policy tightening by the Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank, financial conditions, as measured by our index reflecting financing costs faced by households and firms in housing, credit, and equity markets, have eased considerably in both the United States and the Euro area. This easing has occurred due to investors' relatively optimistic outlook on price pressures, which has contributed to increased market valuations.

This recent easing presents a challenge for central banks in their endeavors to bring inflation back to their 2 percent targets. Traditionally, tighter monetary policy has been transmitted to the real economy and subsequently to inflation through a tightening of financial conditions. Although financial conditions are currently tighter compared to the extremely loose levels observed in mid-2021, the recent easing could complicate the fight against inflation by preventing the necessary slowdown in aggregate demand to mitigate inflationary pressures.

Additionally, the combination of an extended period of loose financial conditions and a tightening monetary policy cycle in advanced economies, which began when inflation was already elevated, further complicates the transmission of monetary policy to financial conditions. For instance, a significant proportion of fixed-rate mortgages with low rates, resulting from refinancing in recent years, exists in the United States. Similarly, corporations have taken advantage of exceptionally low borrowing costs and sufficient liquidity to extend their debt maturities. These factors may have reduced the effectiveness of monetary policy tightening, as many mortgage holders and companies are only now experiencing higher borrowing costs. Consequently, this contributes to the ongoing strength in labor markets and aggregate demand. It is worth noting that other factors, such as structural changes in the labor market or housing markets following the pandemic, could also have played a role.

While financial condition indices based on financing costs in capital markets have improved, monetary policy transmission also occurs through credit extension, particularly for borrowers reliant on bank lending. Bank credit growth remains positive in both the United States and the Euro area, although the pace of growth has slowed significantly, especially in the latter. Recent surveys of loan officers in both regions indicate a considerably slower demand for credit and tightening of underwriting standards by banks, suggesting a potential further deceleration in bank credit provision.

Recent earnings reports from large banks have shown strength, with higher interest rates charged on loans boosting earnings while deposit remuneration continues to lag behind policy tightening. However, lending survey results suggest that profitability could moderate in the future.

Title: Building Resilience in Tuvalu: A Global Imperative

Tuvalu, a nation consisting of nine Pacific islands with a population of 11,000, faces extraordinary challenges from climate change as its islands rise less than five meters above sea level. While domestic policies can support growth in the coming years, the long-term prospects of Tuvalu rely heavily on the global community's ability to prevent destructive global warming outcomes.

Despite experiencing limited health consequences from the pandemic due to prompt containment and widespread vaccination, Tuvalu has suffered significant economic fallout. Economic activity remains below pre-pandemic levels, climate adaptation projects have been delayed, fiscal pressures have increased, and outbound migration threatens Tuvalu's growth potential. Addressing these risks, ranging from climate change to fiscal sustainability, becomes more challenging in light of this setback.

During our recent visit to Tuvalu as part of our regular economic review and consultation with the authorities, we emphasized the importance of comprehensive policies to reduce uncertainty and foster private-sector activity. Enhancing revenue generation and optimizing government spending efficiency will promote fiscal sustainability. Furthermore, fiscal reforms, such as strengthening spending oversight, can facilitate access to climate finance from donors. Given the enormous climate adaptation needs relative to the size of the economy, securing this financing remains critical.

In addition, reforms to strengthen the connectivity of the domestic banking industry to the global payments system, deepen trade integration, and enhance human capital through initiatives like designing scholarships for overseas study are essential for Tuvalu's development. A more diversified economy that builds resilience will also incentivize Tuvaluans to utilize their skills within the country, thereby reducing migration pressures.

However, while domestic policies can contribute significantly to fostering growth in the coming years, Tuvalu's long-term prospects are contingent upon the collective ability of the world to prevent destructive global warming scenarios. Without urgent action, under a high global emissions scenario and with its existing infrastructure, Tuvalu could become uninhabitable by the end of this century due to rising sea levels. This existential threat faced by Tuvalu mirrors the situation of hundreds of millions worldwide who reside in coastal areas.

In conclusion, the plight of Tuvalu due to climate change underscores the responsibility of the global community to intensify efforts in reducing global emissions. Tuvalu's future resilience depends on our collective determination to address this global challenge and safeguard the existence of vulnerable nations.

Ending gender-based violence is a top priority for the World Bank. In 1993, the Declaration of the Elimination of Violence Against Women recognized that violence against women is a violation of their rights and called on states to work towards eradicating it. Unfortunately, even after thirty years, women still face the risk of violence in various settings such as their homes, on the streets, in schools, and at work. It is estimated that one in three women worldwide have experienced intimate partner violence and/or sexual violence from a non-partner in their lifetime. Additionally, gender-based violence includes the millions of girls who are married before the age of 18 and those who have undergone female genital mutilation.

The negative impacts of gender-based violence are significant, affecting not only the survivors but also their children and society as a whole. It hinders the well-being of survivors and their ability to form human capital by subjecting them to negative life experiences. The fear of sexual harassment also limits the mobility and productivity of women and girls, resulting in economic consequences. In fact, a study conducted by the International Finance Corporation in Fiji revealed that perceived threats to safety and reduced productivity at work lead to an average of almost 10 days of lost work per employee each year.

Recognizing the importance of addressing gender-based violence, the World Bank has significantly increased its efforts in prevention and response. Our project work spans across countries, regions, and sectors, often involving partnerships with local, regional, and international governmental and non-governmental organizations. For instance, in Bangladesh, our health project focuses on providing immediate response services and safe spaces for women and girls from the displaced Rohingya population and their host communities. The same program also works towards changing community attitudes and behaviors that perpetuate gender-based violence by adapting the Sasa! program, which aims to transform unequal gender norms.

In Haiti, we collaborate with women-led local civil society organizations to improve the quality and reach of essential services for survivors and women at risk of violence. This project also promotes the social and economic empowerment of women and girls through community-based activities. Similarly, in São Tomé and Príncipe, our education sector project establishes girls' and boys' clubs that empower girls, enhance their socio-emotional skills, and promote positive masculinity to foster safe schools. In India, our transport projects support the government in enhancing the safety of public spaces by mapping and assessing perception of safety and developing policy guidelines that prioritize women's safety in the design of transport networks. Furthermore, in Uzbekistan, our policy financing operation helps survivors of gender-based violence by establishing referral pathways as part of reforms to create inclusive labor markets and encourage female labor force participation.

Our social inclusion and sustainability operations aim to ensure inclusion and empowerment for all individuals, mobilizing collective action to prevent gender-based violence at the community level. For example, in Nigeria, our project focuses on improving economic opportunities for women through building social capital and livelihood support for nearly 20,000 women's groups. The project utilizes the social norms exploratory tool to identify and address the social norms that perpetuate gender inequality.

To further our efforts, we have released a new report, "Gender-Based Violence Prevention and Response in World Bank Operations: Taking Stock After a Decade of Engagement." This report distills the lessons learned over the past ten years and highlights the most promising operational examples from various regions. We have actively engaged with key actors, including ministries of finance, education, health, transport, and social affairs, to prioritize the gender-based violence prevention and response agenda. Our discussions have been informed by global knowledge and consultations with stakeholders such as local women's groups.

Promoting Inclusion and Accessibility for Persons with Disabilities in Latin America and the Caribbean

The importance of prioritizing persons with disabilities during disasters in Latin America and the Caribbean cannot be overstated. Madelyne Castillo, a psychology student at the Public University of Santo Domingo in the Dominican Republic, faces numerous challenges due to the lack of elevators or ramps on campus. Unfortunately, her situation is not unique. Throughout the region, many systems and infrastructure are not designed to accommodate persons with disabilities. This becomes even more problematic when natural disasters strike, as they are occurring more frequently and with increased severity each year.

While early warning systems and preparedness plans can provide assistance, they often overlook the needs of individuals with hearing or vision disabilities. Additionally, the lack of wheelchair accessibility and restrictions on service animals in shelters further exacerbate the difficulties faced by persons with disabilities during disasters. Even after a disaster, the consultation of persons with disabilities is often disregarded when reconstructing infrastructure, resulting in inaccessible environments for them.

Considering that approximately 85 million people in Latin America and the Caribbean live with a disability, it is crucial to address these issues. Globally, 15% of the world's population experiences some form of disability, as defined by the United Nations. Disabilities encompass long-term physical, mental, intellectual, or sensory impairments that, when coupled with attitudinal and environmental barriers, hinder full and equal participation in society.

To tackle these challenges, it is imperative to focus on changing the environment to be more accessible and inclusive. This perspective emphasizes the interaction between individuals and their surroundings, allowing for modifications that accommodate persons with disabilities. In the region, disabilities can result from various causes, including car accidents, chronic diseases like diabetes, labor-related injuries, and violence such as gun violence and gender-based violence. Women with disabilities are particularly vulnerable to gender-based violence, which can further lead to disabilities.

Persons with disabilities face several disadvantages, including limited access to education, poorer health outcomes, lower employment levels, and higher poverty rates. Efforts to increase employment opportunities for persons with disabilities have been made, but the existing barriers to education hinder progress. For instance, in Santo Domingo, only five buses out of many have wheelchair ramps, requiring individuals to rely on others for assistance, thereby compromising their dignity and independence.

However, positive developments are occurring. The Dominican Republic, along with other countries in the region, is demonstrating political will to improve employment opportunities for persons with disabilities. Disabled people's groups are actively engaged and organized, collaborating with their governments to promote inclusion. Strong leadership and commitments from governments have been witnessed in countries like Brazil, Argentina, and Ecuador.

It is essential to foster an inclusive and accessible environment for persons with disabilities in Latin America and the Caribbean. By addressing the barriers they face and promoting their full participation in society, we can create a more equitable and just region.

Countries are taking proactive measures to enhance their preparedness in responding to future food and nutrition security crises in 2022. These crises can be triggered by conflicts, economic shocks, natural disasters, and rising fertilizer and food prices. Unfortunately, the poorest people are the ones who suffer the most from these crises. In 2023, the situation is expected to worsen, with both acute and chronic levels deteriorating further.

The Global Report on Food Crises 2022 Mid-Year Update indicates that the number of people requiring urgent humanitarian assistance is projected to reach up to 205 million in 45 countries/territories covered in the report. This necessitates immediate action to protect lives and livelihoods and prevent the erosion of hard-earned development progress. Time is of the essence in responding to such crises, as delays can amplify their severity and prolong vulnerabilities, undermining resilience to future shocks.

Crisis preparedness, which involves the ability to anticipate, respond to, and recover from major shocks, is crucial in addressing these issues. To promote better preparedness for food and nutrition security crises, the World Bank, in collaboration with the Global Alliance for Food Security (GAFS), the Global Network Against Food Crises (GNAFC), the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), UNICEF, WFP, and the UN Famine Prevention and Response Coordinator, is supporting countries in developing and implementing Food Security Crisis Preparedness Plans (FSCPPs).

An FSCPP is a national operational plan that outlines the criteria for identifying a major food and nutrition security crisis in a country. It also outlines protocols, roles, and timelines for mobilizing additional funding and scaling up early action. By bringing together various elements of crisis preparedness into a coherent framework, FSCPPs facilitate the timely recognition of emerging crises and prompt coordinated responses across government, humanitarian, and development partners to prevent and mitigate their impacts.

The FSCPP draws on the strengths of over 60 multilateral and bilateral partners involved in GAFS, the Global Food and Nutrition Security Dashboard, and GNAFC. It is guided by seven key principles:

1. Government ownership and leadership: Whenever possible, the government takes the lead in developing and managing the FSCPP, involving relevant national and local institutions and agencies. In cases where the government's operational capacity is limited, the international community supports these functions until the government can effectively take over.

2. Focus on major food and nutrition security crises: The FSCPP prioritizes shocks that have widespread and severe consequences across the country, extending beyond existing chronic issues. It ensures that responses are mobilized through government, humanitarian, and development channels.

3. Evidence-based: The FSCPP relies on rigorous, well-vetted, and timely food and nutrition security information from various sources to provide a comprehensive understanding of emerging risks.

4. Holistic approach: In the event of a major crisis, the FSCPP calls for swift scaling up and coordination of activities across government, humanitarian, and development partners. It leverages the unique strengths of each partner to save lives, protect livelihoods, and enhance resilience to future shocks.

5. Do no harm: The FSCPP takes into account country and local contexts, considering how responses may interact with and impact existing economic, political, and social dynamics, particularly for vulnerable populations.

SCO Celebrates Formal Ownership of Landmark HBC Building as Historic Act of Reconciliation Takes Next Step

March 30, 2023

Anishinaabe and Dakota Territory, MB - The Southern Chiefs' Organization (SCO) is delighted to announce that the landmark HBC building in downtown Winnipeg has been officially transferred to our organization. On behalf of the 34 Anishnaabe and Dakota nations in southern Manitoba, SCO is pleased to share new details and images regarding the transformation of this iconic structure, located at the corner of Portage Avenue and Memorial Boulevard in Treaty One territory.

"The formal transfer of the HBC building to SCO on the Wehwehneh Bahgahkinahgohn project is a momentous occasion for Southern First Nations," stated SCO Grand Chief Jerry Daniels. "Although there is still much work to be done in order to transform the space, this building will become a home to hundreds of families, providing childcare services, a health and healing center, a remarkable museum, restaurants, a place of commemoration to honor survivors, and much more. This journey signifies a vital step towards reconciliation."

In the spring of 2022, SCO welcomed HBC Governor Richard Baker and Prime Minister Trudeau to our territory. Together with the Southern Chiefs, the Premier, the Mayor, and community leaders, we announced plans to transform the HBC heritage building into a venue that promotes economic and social reconciliation. Since the announcement, SCO and HBC have worked closely to ensure a smooth transfer. Wehwehneh Bahgahkinahgohn, which means 'it is visible,' will revitalize the HBC building while preserving its rich heritage and contributing to the revitalization of downtown Winnipeg.

"HBC is immensely proud to further our partnership with SCO and achieve this milestone by officially transferring ownership of the building," said Richard Baker, Governor of HBC. "We remain committed allies to SCO as they work to realize their incredible vision for this new space, and we hope that others will be inspired to take meaningful action towards reconciliation in their own way."

SCO has issued a request for qualifications to initiate the redevelopment process using a competitive approach, ensuring the best value for the project. This redevelopment marks the largest transformation of a historic building in Manitoba and is one of the most significant projects of its kind in Canada. Our aim is to reopen the building in November 2026, coinciding with its 100th anniversary.

Nearly a century ago, the construction of the HBC building at 450 Portage Avenue involved 300 men, 120 teams of horses, 20 trucks, and two steam shovels to excavate 150,000 tons of earth for the foundation of the store. Upon its opening in 1926, the structure, designed by Canadian architect Ernest Isbell Barrott, became the largest reinforced concrete building in Canada, boasting over six hectares of floor space.

The Wehwehneh Bahgahkinahgohn project includes plans for over 300 affordable housing units for families and post-secondary students, as well as culturally safe assisted living units for First Nation elders. Residents and employees of the building will also have access to much-needed, high-quality licensed childcare services and a rooftop garden. The project prioritizes the improvement of First Nation peoples' health and wellness, with a health and healing center that combines both Western and traditional practices.

Moreover, this historic building will serve as the future governance house for the chiefs of the Southern First Nations, representing the voice of the 34 Anishinaabe and Dakota nations in the territory now known as Manitoba. The main floor will be dedicated public space, welcoming Manitobans, Canadians, and tourists from around the world to come together and experience a world-class museum that shares the history of the Anishinaabe and Dakota peoples, partly through artifacts reclaimed from the Vatican vaults. The building will also provide essential space for ceremonies and commemorations, including a memorial to honor the survivors of residential and day schools, as well as the children who never returned home.

Today, the Poverty and Inequality Platform (PIP) released updated global poverty estimates, taking into account the challenges of estimating poverty during the pandemic. This update includes new regional poverty aggregates for Latin America and the Caribbean, Europe and Central Asia, and the group of advanced countries. We now have sufficient survey data available for these regions during the COVID-19 pandemic, with a total of 113 new country-years added, bringing the total number of surveys to over 2,100.

In addition to the new data, this update incorporates the usual changes to input data, such as revisions to existing welfare distributions, the inclusion of new welfare distributions, and revisions to price, national accounts, and population data used for global poverty monitoring. However, these changes have resulted in only minor revisions to global and regional poverty estimates.

Table 1 provides a summary of the revisions to the regional and global poverty estimates between the September 2022 and March 2023 data vintages for the reference year 2019, at all three poverty lines. At a poverty line of $2.15, the global poverty headcount ratio has been revised slightly upward by 0.1 percentage points to 8.5 percent, resulting in a revision in the number of poor people from 648 to 659 million. This revision represents an increase of 11 million people living in extreme poverty, largely driven by South Asia (5 million) and the Middle East and North Africa (4 million).

Similar limited changes in poverty estimates are observed at the higher poverty lines of $3.65 and $6.85, which are typically used for measuring poverty in lower-middle and upper-middle-income countries respectively. At $3.65, the global poverty headcount ratio increases by 0.1 percentage points to 23.6 percent, representing 28 million more people living in poverty. At $6.85, the global poverty rate increases by 0.2 percentage points to 46.9 percent, representing 44 million people living in poverty. The upward revisions in poverty estimates at the higher lines are largely driven by South Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa.

This March 2023 Global Poverty Update from the World Bank revises previously published global and regional estimates from 1981 to 2019. Regional poverty estimates are now reported up to 2021, depending on sufficient data coverage during the COVID-19 pandemic. For Europe and Central Asia, poverty data are reported until 2020, and for Latin America and the Caribbean until 2021. For all other developing regions, poverty data are reported for pre-pandemic years.

It's important to note that the data published in this PIP update, while incorporating more recent input data, do not change the overall perceptions about global poverty trends and the regional distribution of poverty. Global poverty has been declining since the 1990s, albeit at a slower rate since 2014. Extreme poverty has been decreasing in all regions, except the Middle East and North Africa due to conflict and fragility. In 2019, approximately 60% of the world's extreme poor lived in Sub-Saharan Africa alone, while 81% of the global poor at the poverty line of $3.65 lived in Sub-Saharan Africa or South Asia.

It has been approximately four months since Turkey experienced two significant earthquakes measuring 7.8 and 7.5 on the Richter scale on February 6, 2023. These were followed by numerous aftershocks and another strong earthquake measuring 6.7 on February 20, 2023. The earthquakes caused extensive damage in 11 provinces in southern Turkey, home to 14 million Turkish citizens and 1.8 million Syrian refugees, representing 16% of the country's population. According to the World Bank and the Global Facility for Disaster Reduction and Recovery (GFDRR), the estimated initial direct physical damages amounted to $34.2 billion, with the Turkish government and its partners predicting recovery and reconstruction costs to exceed $81 billion.

Among the areas significantly impacted were education buildings, with around 5% of the 20,000 buildings in the affected regions collapsing or suffering severe to moderate damage. However, amidst the ongoing recovery and reconstruction efforts, a remarkable story has emerged regarding the resilience of recently constructed schools. Through a partnership between Turkey, the World Bank, GFDRR, and the European Union (EU), schools built in accordance with Turkey's latest seismic code, updated in 2018 to align with international earthquake engineering standards, withstood the devastating earthquakes. 

Since 2017, Turkey's Ministry of National Education, with support from the World Bank, GFDRR, and the EU through its Facility for Refugees in Turkey (FRIT), has constructed 57 schools, comprising over 1,400 classrooms, under the Education Infrastructure for Resilience Project. All 24 schools located in the areas affected by the February 2023 earthquakes and aftershocks remained intact. Fortunately, the earthquakes occurred outside of school hours, ensuring the safety of students and educators. Murat Çiçekdal, the school manager for Martyr Ercan Sanca Primary School, expressed, "Most parents came to inspect the school and noticed there was not even the slightest crack or plaster damage. We have seamlessly resumed our educational activities from where we left off before the earthquake."

Four schools in Kahramanmaraş province have been used by the Turkish government as temporary shelters and for providing essential services to affected populations. Across Turkey, it is estimated that over 40,000 individuals now have access to safer and more resilient schools due to the Ministry of National Education's Safe Schools initiative, supported by the Education Infrastructure for Resilience Project. Approximately half of these beneficiaries are female. In addition to seismic safety, each of the 57 schools constructed under this project adheres to Turkish codes and regulations on land use planning, energy efficiency, fire protection, workplace safety, and accessibility for people with disabilities. The outcome has been a safer and enhanced learning environment for students and trainees.

Turkey has been at the forefront of promoting the agenda for safer schools, recognizing the need for resilient education infrastructure in one of the world's most earthquake-prone countries. Since 2015, Turkey has partnered with the World Bank and GFDRR, including through the Global Program for Safer Schools (GPSS), to ensure the safety and resilience of schools nationwide. GFDRR, in particular, has facilitated the exchange of international experiences on safer schools, established a program for reducing seismic risk, and supported the expansion of disaster-resilient education infrastructure through initiatives like the Education Infrastructure for Resilience Project and the Disaster Risk Management in Schools Project.

Moving forward, the World Bank and GFDRR remain committed to assisting Turkey in its recovery and rebuilding efforts following the devastating earthquakes. Additionally, they will continue to lay the foundation for a more resilient future by supporting Turkey's efforts to enhance disaster resilience.

International Youth Day on August 15, 2023, is a global celebration of the contributions of young individuals and their potential to create a more sustainable and inclusive world. As the challenges of environmental degradation become more urgent, it is crucial to equip young people with the tools to promote sustainable development. One of the key ways to achieve this is through media and information literacy (MIL), which empowers youth with the knowledge and critical thinking skills needed to navigate complex environmental issues and develop green skills for a more sustainable future.

As we celebrate International Youth Day, it is important to recognize the role of media and information literacy in fostering green skills among young individuals. By providing youth with the ability to critically engage with media content and make informed decisions, we empower them to become leaders in sustainable development. MIL not only enhances their understanding of environmental issues but also enables them to drive change, promote eco-friendly practices, and contribute to a greener and more sustainable future for generations to come.

Green skills encompass a range of competencies and knowledge aimed at environmental sustainability. These skills enable individuals to contribute to eco-friendly practices, develop innovative solutions for environmental challenges, and actively participate in the transition to a greener and more sustainable economy. They cover areas such as renewable energy, waste reduction, conservation, sustainable agriculture, and more. By acquiring these skills, young people can play a vital role in driving sustainable development and mitigating the impacts of climate change.

MIL serves as a catalyst for the development and promotion of green skills among youth. In a world flooded with information, misinformation, and rapidly evolving technologies, MIL equips young individuals with the ability to critically assess and analyze media content, discern credible sources, and make informed decisions. It empowers them to filter through the noise, identify reliable information, and gain a deep understanding of environmental issues and solutions. MIL enables young people to access a wealth of information on environmental conservation, climate change, and sustainable practices through various media channels, including websites, documentaries, podcasts, and social media. They can learn about successful green initiatives, cutting-edge technologies, and inspiring stories of environmental stewardship. By developing media and information literacy skills, youth can amplify their impact by sharing accurate and impactful information with their peers, communities, and the wider world.

MIL encourages critical thinking and problem-solving skills, which are essential for tackling complex environmental challenges. Young people with MIL skills can analyze data, evaluate policy proposals, and think creatively about sustainable solutions. By critically engaging with information, they can contribute to informed discussions and decision-making processes related to environmental issues, advocating for policies that prioritize sustainability. MIL empowers young individuals to become agents of change by fostering innovation and entrepreneurship. Equipped with accurate information and critical thinking abilities, youth can identify gaps in the market for sustainable products and services. They can develop and launch green start-ups, creating solutions that address environmental challenges while generating economic opportunities. MIL enables them to navigate the business landscape, connect with mentors, and access resources that support their entrepreneurial endeavors.

UNESCO, as the leading organization promoting media and information literacy, empowers people to think critically about information and the use of digital tools. It helps individuals make informed choices about their participation in peacebuilding, equality, freedom of expression, dialogue, access to information, and sustainable development. UNESCO supports and champions media and information literacy initiatives worldwide.
